title: C1 Tone changed after 1.12 upgrade
post_content: Hello everybody,I'm writing on behalf of a friend that I helped to upgrade his C1 Organ OS from 1.0 to 1.12, just today.We made the upgrade today, and everything went OK.From the the techie side, the only problem we had was that on an intel iMac the upgrade program didn't run, and we had to upgrade using an old G4 Macbook (maybe some binary incompatibility with intel OSX 1.8.5, who knows…).But the main problem now seems the overall "keyboard tone", that my friend says it's changed, more "boxed", less dynamic, more "cheap", especially with the lower keyboard tones…He's going to perform in this very moment, so I cannot be more precise about the problem (I had only a brief telephone chat, and I'll invite him to write some more detailed description, if necessary), but meanwhile I'm asking to you in the forum:1) Did anyone experience any kind of tone variation just after upgrading the keyboard OS (presets and parameters were maintained)?2) Would it be expected (I don't think so, but…)?3) Having OS 1.12 up and running, will a "factory reset" turn back to the old 1.0 OS version? Or will it reset to 1.12?4) In case answer 3 in "NO", Is there a way to downgrade the firmware to 1.0?Any suggestion is welcome …thank you in advanceEnrico Dell'Aquila

title: RE: C1 Tone changed after 1.12 upgrade
post_content: I don't have a C1 organ so I can't say anything specifically about that one.Did your friend use presets (programs) to check the sound? I'm not sure if this is the case or not, but perhaps the factory presets need to be updated. Perhaps they slightly changed the way they are stored, etc. I would suggest making a backup of the current sounds and then sending a fresh copy of the factory defaults to the C1 again to overwrite them. If you made a backup, you can always restore that.To make a backup or to send the factory sounds to the C1, you need a computer with a MIDI interface. The procedure is briefly described on page 19 of the C1 manual.Here it is in a bit more detail:Make sure the MIDI interface is connected to your computer and is working. Connect the C1 with the MIDI interface; MIDI OUT on the C1 connects to MIDI IN on the interface and MIDI OUT on the interface connects to MIDI IN on the C1.Install a utility to send/receive MIDI SysEx data. For Windows I would suggest Bome's Send SX (http://www.bome.com/products/sendsx) and for the Mac SysEx Librarian (http://www.snoize.com/SysExLibrarian/) - both are free, but there might be limitations on commercial use for Send SX.Start the SysEx utility and set it up to receive a backup from the C1 - check the documentation for the utility you're using to see how to do that. In SysEx Librarian on the Mac, I think you just click the 'Record Many' button in the top-right of the window.Go into the System menu of the C1 (page 15-16 of the manual) and select Dump All. This sends a SysEx dump with all the current programs to the SysEx utility.Now check and make sure Memory Protect is turned off on the C1 (see page 15 of the manual).Make sure you have downloaded (from the Downloads section for the C1 on the Nord website) the zip file with the factory sounds - it is only a very small file. Extract this file somewhere you can find it. It will contain a single file with a .syx extension.Load the .syx file with the factory sounds into the SysEx utility and send it to the C1. According to the manual (page 19) the display of the C1 will display 'rCu' while it is receiving the data - wait for the utility to finish sending the SysEx dump.Now check the presets again for sound quality. If you want to restore the old sounds (backup), performs steps 5 thru 7 again but use the backup you made earlier.As for your specific questions:No idea, I don't have a C1While I can imagine presets sounding different (I've had this on a different Nord), I would expect the sound quality to be the same or better after an update. This is also why I suggest updating the factory sounds.It wouldn't have any effect, it would stay at 1.12.If you can find the older firmware (I looked briefly, but wasn't able to find it) you can probably down-grade to an older version. Not an ideal solution though, since it seems 1.12 contains quite a number of important fixes according to the update history.If updating the factory sounds has no effect (or you cannot find or borrow a MIDI interface) I suggest contacting Clavia about this via the support section on their website. You can also contact the distributor for your region (click on the Distributors link at the top of the Clavia/Nord website) - the advantage of this is that it might be easier to communicate with them, since you can just do it in Italian.I would appreciate it if you can post a short update for this issue once you have more info or, hopefully, have it solved; this might be helpful for some other C1 owner who runs into this issue in the future.

title: RE: C1 Tone changed after 1.12 upgrade
post_content: Thank you for the quick response, we'll try the factory sounds update ASAP.I'm not sure we have a MIDI interface available right now (we made everything via USB), but we'll find one if necessary.I'll let you know...thank you againEnrico

title: RE: C1 Tone changed after 1.12 upgrade
post_content: UPDATE:Contacted Clavia directly through their website contact page.They confirmed that the new OS version has changed sound management and some functions (rotary, click, percussion, etc..) for a better simulation.Does it change the tone? We're still not sure, but they were kindly sending via the official distributor an old 1.02 OS update, that we'll try to install ASAP, and see (hear) if anything changes...I'll keep you informed.Enrico

title: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: So, ordered the PK27 pedals the same time as purchasing the C2D, back in August.Here in Australia, the importer is The a Electric Factory in Melbourne.I was told that the pedals would come in the next shipment, roughly 4-6 weeks.Now it's October, 6 weeks later. I rang to see what was the go, and was told they won't be here until February!!!!!!  That's 6 months to ship some 16kg pedals to Australia!!!!What's the go? Why? What? How?I told them that that was unacceptable, and the reply was "we'll see if we can get them earlier"Der!!!Should I contact Nord HQ directly?Thoughts and experiences please...

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: Why not just order them from someplace else?

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: I ordered mine from Thomann 3 weeks ago, knowing they were out of stock. I figured I'd get them as quickly from there as anywhere, since few dealers hold them in stock anyway. They are now on their way - I had the email saying so 2 1/2 weeks after I placed the order. I guess they make small batches at Nord, so that's probably the next batch, but if your order was in the pipeline, it would have been fulfilled on that basis and on its way to your dealer by now. I suspect your dealer has been a bit slack and not chased them up as hard as he could - I have known dealers ignore the first order for anything and only placing the order when you start chasing for delivery, probably so they don't get landed with orders that people don't want by the time the stuff arrives.If you can import them directly yourself, I'd try that. 6 months is a joke. You can try emailing Nord to see what they say. They ought to know if dealers are messing their customers about.

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: I just checked, and it looks as if Thomann will ship to Australia, so if the tax and duty arrangements suit you it might work. Some people have reported poor packaging from Thomann, but everything I've had from them has been properly packed and arrived safely. In Europe their prices are pretty keen, so I should have a look and see what you think.You'll need to take the pre-VAT price on the website, make your currency conversion (it does it automatically for European countries but I doubt if it does for Oz). Then you'll have to add your home tax (GST?) and any import duty (probably the other way round - I bet you have to pay sales tax on the duty!) as I imagine a set of pedals will be over the item limit for tax-free imports.

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: Thanks Tacitus for your detailed repliesI wrote an email directly to the Australian distributer for Nord explaining my situation and received a pleasant reply. To quote in paraphrase:"we order 4 months in advance and there is 8 to 10 weeks shipping time.About three weeks before we got your August order we sold out of Pedal Keys and didn't have any more scheduled. My fault.""xxxx xxxx of xxxxxx brought you to our attention and we immediately requested extra stock.At some stage tomorrow I will provide xxxx an accurate eta for the PK 27 on it's way so he can put your mind to rest.We apologise for the delay... "I'm hoping sooner rather than later

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: tacitus wrote:Some people have reported poor packaging from Thomann, but everything I've had from them has been properly packed and arrived safely.I have had nothing but outstanding service from Thomann.  Three shipments to Canada quickly (DHL). Packaging was great.

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: I think the overall service from Thomann is good to outstanding. I'm not saying somebody made up stories of poor packaging, but I suppose even the best of us have the occasional off day. In any case, even that particular story didn't result in a damaged product, as far as I know.I try to buy locally in the UK when I can, but for something specialised like the Nord products, you do seem to be able to get the accessories much more easily from Thomann. I ended up getting the C2D itself and the case for the pedals in the UK and the rest from Thomann. Should get the pedals any day now and then my rig is complete (until I get the Leslie 3300, that is ...).

title: RE: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: I've checked my A100 and the Pedalkeys.Both are identically placed over the E-F pedals.The difference is the Pedalkeys line up with the lowest C on the keyboard, where on all B, C and A's the pedals are aligned with the E pedal being below the bottom C key on the manuals.I was wondering why I was missing some pedals, saw this and have simply adjusted my playing. Not a big deal, and being pro I just adjust to whatever I play. Funny thing is there's always, always something wrong with all vintage Hammonds, and we deal with it as part of the joy!If I was pedantic, I could move the C2D a few inches to the right to align the low c to the E pedal, but seriously, I'm simply gonna adapt.

title: PK27 .... 6mth wait for delivery!!!
post_content: Thanks for responding, Cam. Yeah, I guess I just need to adjust my playing. The funny thing is, Nord went to the trouble of designing the Pedal Keys to match real Hammond pedals exactly (see photo) and then design the ALU stand so that you can't sit the Pedal Keys far enough to the left to put the C2D's manuals in the correct relative position. Still, it's a great set-up for gigging and the C2D's an awesome instrument. For those of us who have OCD, they should make an OC2D.Cheers,-Brandon.p.s. Been jamming on Pop It with my trio. Everyone loves that tune! Including my wife, which is rare for a hammond tune.

title: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Hello people. I'm a happy owner of a Nord C2D and I believe that is the best clonewheel out. However, I don't like the sub bass response frequencies, walking notes on left hand (jazz style). Comparing with VB3/Crumar Mojo (I have the software only), I feel the sub bass much more present in the plugin. I tried some ways to fix that with onboard EQ, unsuccefful. Is there any way to improve the Nord at this point? Maybe an item to enhance in a future update? Thank you.From Brasil,Geovanni.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Hey,I know what you mean. The C2/D bass is not killing with a massive body. More a decent one.When I owned the Sk1 the Bass was huge - plus could be mixed with the lower manual. So I could design it much more.Great clone but Bass is not a Floorquaker.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Are you using the internal sim?Are you using a volume pedal?I have the VB3 to the leslie sim is very bass rich in VB3.Try an set the sim to bass 70 rotor 30Make sure you have so much volume that you play with the swell backed of.Turn up the bass eq to three o clock.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Thanks guys.Here's my sound setup:Mode: Vintage 2KeyClick: HigherSpeaker: 122closeBass/Horn: 70/30EQ: Bass +3 / Mid -3 / Hi -4Drive: +4Reverb: Hall 1, +4EQ, Drive and Reverb are variables, depends on my humorBTW, Tony Monaco is filming a video called "clones 4 real", that he will show how to setup clonewhells to sound like real hammond. I think it will be very interesting and useful.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Pretty close to my settingsWhat is essential is to have so much volume that you can play with the swell pedal all the way back. The swell should be used for dynamics not as a volume control.Use the master for that.If you need to come down you push in the drawbars. They are volumes to.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Geovanni Andrade wrote:Thanks guys.Here's my sound setup:Mode: Vintage 2KeyClick: HigherSpeaker: 122closeBass/Horn: 70/30EQ: Bass +3 / Mid -3 / Hi -4Drive: +4Reverb: Hall 1, +4EQ, Drive and Reverb are variables, depends on my humorBTW, Tony Monaco is filming a video called "clones 4 real", that he will show how to setup clonewhells to sound like real hammond. I think it will be very interesting and useful.I am looking forward to Tony's video as well. title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: flmc59 wrote:Pretty close to my settingsWhat is essential is to have so much volume that you can play with the swell pedal all the way back. The swell should be used for dynamics not as a volume control.Use the master for that.If you need to come down you push in the drawbars. They are volumes to.I tried this, and well, it really works! I feel a little bit more bass and less mid and high frequencies, with sweel pedal at zero (I have a roland Pk9. I use Roland EV5 when i can't carry the pedalboard).I was playing normally with the pedal in the middle of the way.Thanks!

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: The reason for this is that the swell pedal of Hammond is both volume and parametric filter at the same time.So with the pedal all the way back the mid is very attenuated.As you press down the curve is flatened at same time as the volume is raised.So by raising the maste volume you can use the mid attenuated part of the travel of the swell.This is the same as turning upThe bass and trebble control and turning down the mid.The difference is quite large

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: The C2(D)'s bass sound isn't that far off of what is generated by a real B3, except in a real B3 the depth in the bass is mainly boosted by the characteristics of the tubes, it's that boost that's missing on the Nord.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: No, I do not think so. My C2D is connected to a leslie 122 XB, and despite the tubes leslie, the first octave of the left hand is sorely lacking in bass, especially the keys from E1 to B1.must be faster than North forms an update to correct this problem.I also think the C3 chorus and percussion could still be improved.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: Each version of nordorgans has added bass to the lower end.Have you compared with an b3 in your Leslie?Btw-what characteristic does tubes have in that enhances bass?A tube amp with flat curve is as flat as transistor based amp. Flat is flat regardless of media

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: If it just a matter of amp feequency responce you can fix it with an graphic eq.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: What tubes do is making the sound more audible via adding some extra (3rd?) harmonics.So does my tube preamp with 2 tubes inside. Certainly the warmed-up sound loses brightness.I think the C2/D bass is too transparent. When I play it sub with the lowest register there is too muchtransparency, when I mix the other register to it, the sound bites too much through. Like an other memberhas written - the bass has to be redone.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: The leslie tube amp isn't the only amp, in a B3 the AO-28 tube preamp also defines the characteristics of the sound.I agree that what the C2(D) puts out isn't the deep bass we all would like to hear, and yes I agree on room for an update there.The only weak points of the Nord C2(D) i.m.o. :- Lack of deep bass but- Having annoying uppertones in the bass- The characteristic volume increase at A1 that a B3 does have, is too exaggerated- Lack of Pedal attack/pluck- Lack of a "spring-reverb" emulation- Lack of Pedal sustain- C3 effect isn't real enough- 3th Percussion isn't real or tweakable enough, soundwiseWhen these would be fixed, it would be the ultimate clonewheel by far i.m.o.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: "the first octave of the left hand is sorely lacking in bass, especially the keys from E1 to B1."Gosh, I wonder why that is? It's almost like the bottom octave drops out.

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: The C2(D) mimicks a real B3, so you also get the foldback in the lowest and highest octaves. Ok, it would make a nice FEATURE to have a setting to switch low foldback off. But in the end we all want it to sound lika a real B3 don't we ?

title: RE: C2D sub bass response
post_content: This is from the Nord website:Our simulation not only reacts to the panel settings but even adapts to the real time performanceand will faithfully reproduce the important foldback and energy robbing characteristics; the latter produces the gentle compression effect that makes those lovely smears absolutely wonderful.There are 4 tone wheel modes available, ranging from the default vintage battered workhorse with plenty of leakage to a clean factory spec'd instrument.

title: My brand new C2D arrived broken  ;(
post_content: So, every thing is split at the G3 area in this weird way:  i get the upper's sound on the bottom half of the bottom keyboard, and nothing on the bottom half of the upper keyboard.  Vice versa, I get the lower preset on the lower half of the upper keyboard, but nothing on the upper half of the bottom keyboard.  It's as if each manual crosses paths @ the G3/G#3 point.  sooo frustrated right now.   I feel like someone @ the factory plugged the wrong half of each keyboard into the wrong circuit board, or something like that. I'm no technician. For $3600/$4000, I shouldn't have to deal with this.It does this effect for all organ selections.  At first, I was like: "how come I only have percussion for half of the keyboard?"  nope, it's there, at the bottom half of the bottom keyboard.Btw, everything else about this keyboard is absolutely fabulous. the drawbars are so much nicer than roland's vr-09. Everything about it is solid.Here's hoping it's a split that isn't mentioned in the instruction manual.V 1.04, btw.

title: RE: My brand new C2D arrived broken  ;(
post_content: Sounds like the factory needs to improve their final quality inspection. Pretty sad if two sets of cables were inverted and not checked, we're not talking about a cheap chinese kids keyboard here...

The Nord tour video leads you to believe that their quality control is super high.They should track who messed up with the UPC codes they use and have them personally issue you an apology!

title: RE: My brand new C2D arrived broken  ;(
post_content: I have a funny feeling that Nord is making C2D's as fast as they possibly can!  I'd wager they can hardly keep up with the demand.

title: RE: C2D Leslie sim good enough?
post_content: Hi,The sim 145 is perfect for a good sound on a record, wirh overdrive to 4.regards.

title: RE: B3 in NE3
post_content: I tried a Neo Vent in order to improve my NE3 Leslie Sim. After a week of tests, I gave that pedal back : no great improvement ... I mean not enough to justify the Neo Vent price. Yes, you can clearly hear the sound spinnig around you but when you play with other musicians, no one in the audience can hear the difference between Neo Vent or NE3 Leslie internal sim.

title: RE: B3 in NE3
post_content: I think you're over-thinking this, S-V-S - I know because I've gone through exactly the same process until I finally bought my C2D. In my case, it was between the C2D and the Hammond XK3C, but in the end I figured that both had enthusiasts and detractors, with regard to both the B3 emulation and the Leslie emulation, so I decided in the end that as I wanted the baroque organ and the whole thing would be cheaper, I'd go for the C2D. In a band, or even playing solo, the differences are much smaller than the breadth of a man's talent, and if you can play the thing, that's fine. If you can't, well ... .Also, I discovered that physically moving air with a real rotary is the best, even if it's not tubes and even if it's not an actual Leslie. But the moving air thing might be lost if you mike up a Leslie in a band, so you need the 3300 to have a bit more volume and even then it might not be enough for a loud rock band.99% of punters will not know or care: the other 1% would most likely be fooled if you put your sim through the PA and stood a dummy Leslie at the back of the stage somewhere! Come to think of it, you could have one on wheels and put all your other gear in it for transport.

title: How to wire my C2D into my KRK Rokit 5 G3 powered monitors?
post_content: I am looking to use my studio monitors with my C2D while practicing at home.  But I don't exactly know how to connect the C2D to the monitors.  The monitors have and unbalanced RCA input, a balanced 1/4 TRS input, and a XLR input.  Since the CD2 outputs are unbalanced 1/4, how do I get from them to the monitors?  I can't plug a unbalanced signal (via a 1/4 instrument cable) into a balanced one can I?Any info would be great!Thanks,-Ryan

title: RE: How to wire my C2D into my KRK Rokit 5 G3 powered monitors?
post_content: Easy way is to use a Twin RCA to RCA lead such as you'd use for your hi-fi (you'll need to split one end to get the two plugs to the speakers) and use a couple of RCA to 1/4" adapters to make the other end fit the organ. They're a couple of dollars and have a 1/4" plug with an RCA socket built on the end.If you can solder, even better to make up a lead with 1/4" plugs one end and RCA the other, but the solution above is fine for most purposes - I just wouldn't gig with a load of adapters like that, though lots of people do.You can go from unbalanced to balanced, but it depends on the way your balanced inputs are engineered on how much volume you lose. Going 1/4" to RCA is the right match of signal levels even if the connectors are different.

title: RE: How to wire my C2D into my KRK Rokit 5 G3 powered monitors?
post_content: Hey.But I would NOT use (accidentally) the MONO HIGH OUTPUT of the C2D. Have fun.BTW, the subwoofer 10s brings much more fun into KRK sound

title: RE: How to wire my C2D into my KRK Rokit 5 G3 powered monitors?

title: RE: How to wire my C2D into my KRK Rokit 5 G3 powered monitors?
post_content: I prefer to simply connect my Nord to my KRK Rokit 6 G2 monitors using two separate 3 meter cables with 6.35 mm jacks (mono/TR) on each end. The Rokits will see you plugged in an unbalanced source and will treat it accordingly. This leaves the RCA inputs free, which I sometimes connect an iPhone to using a regular 3.5 mm stereo jack to dual RCA cable.I haven't tried it, but I suppose you can at least use both the RCA and balanced (either XLR or jack, probably not both) at the same time. I could maybe play a song on the iPhone and play along on my Nord.

title: RE: How to wire my C2D into my KRK Rokit 5 G3 powered monitors?
post_content: And if that doesn't work, plug the iPod into the Nord and use the headphone out to drive the speakers. Can't see why that shouldn't be fine for practicing at home, even if it's not the highest possible quality.

title: Can you hear the Leslie even if you don't play anything?

title: RE: Can you hear the Leslie even if you don't play anything?
post_content: If the organ patch you're playing uses the B3 model of the older, neglected B3, you will hear the Leslie spinning even with no note being played, just like an older, neglected B3.  It's in the owner's manual.

If you run out of things to tweak, you can always trade it in for an XK3C, which will give you even more stuff like this to fiddle about with. title: Nord C2D Dimensions (Half-Moon Switch & Music Rest)
post_content: I'm looking at building a customer hard case for the C2D and planning on getting the half-moon switch and the wide music rest.  I might cut out a cavity for the music rest.  Nord published the width and height as 70 x 25 cm (27.6" x 9.8").  Does anyone own the extra wide music rest and know what the depth required for an internal cavity in a hard case would be to store the music stand underneath the keyboard.Likewise, what are the dimensions of the half-moon switch and what is the measurement from the left side of the Nord C2D where the half-moon switch protrudes form the lower manual?  I'm looking to put enough foam in front of the lower manual to allow for a cutout for the half-moon switch.Any experience with leaving the half-moon switch in place with a case that accommodates or is that a bad idea due if you inadvertently smash the switch when you are packing/unpacking it from the hardcase?

title: RE: Nord C2D Dimensions (Half-Moon Switch & Music Rest)
post_content: The half-moon switch will fit in any of four positions along the front of the manuals, so you need to know where you're going to put it. Alternatively, plan to sit the C2D in a recess on the lid of the case and make the rest of the case fit over it. That way, you can plonk the while thing on the keyboard and then take the top off and hey, presto, you're ready to go. Plus, the wire from the half-moon to the socket on the back will be trapped between the organ and the case so you don't snag it.When I can get at my C2D I'll get some measurements - I have the music rest and the half-moon switch, so I should be able to give you the info you need some time tomorrow. I bought the soft case, which so far seems to be OK, but I haven't taken it out much yet. I know it's not cheap, but this is the first time I've had the chance to buy the whole kit in one go, so I took it. I got a reasonable deal on the C2D itself, which has effectively paid for the half-moon, the music rest, the C2D soft case and most of the Pedal key soft case. Of all the bits, I'm least happy with the music rest, because it's quite a way off from me. Not a bad distance for my varifocals, but still trying for small print. I might build an adapter to bring it forward and to raise it so I can still get at the controls underneath.

title: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: I just received my Nord C2 stand (my C2D doesn't get here until Tuesday), and I've got a question.  What's the deal with the two long pieces of padding that go on top of the ends of the stand?  In every picture of a C2 on this stand that I've seen, the organ sits in-between the ends and not on top. Seems to me that thinner pieces of padding to go on the insides of each stand end (to protect the wood sides of the C2) would make more sense?  Maybe I am missing something?Thanks,Ryan

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: There's a leaflet with the stand that explains this: The actual picture shows the padded strip on the top face of the end bars, but if you read the words (in some sort of chinese/swedish english) you will see they propose the option of cutting the pieces to fit on the inside faces of the end bars to stop the wooden sides of the organ from becoming scratched. That's what I did with my stand that arrives only a couple of days ago. I have no idea why they thonk you'd want the padding on the top unless you're using the stand for something else entirely.

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: The piece of paper that came with my stand instructs you (with pictures, no words) to put the long padding strips (A) on the top of the ends.  That's why I asked, because it didn't make sense to me!  Thanks for the info!

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: Odd that there's two versions of that leaflet - mine has the picture as you describe, but then the words at the bottom telling you to stick them on the sides if you want to protect the instrument's end-cheeks. Maybe they did it wrong and reprinted it with the message instead of drawing a new diagram ...

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: does seem odd, but there aren't any written directions (words).  I have another stand coming in a day or two.  I'll check out those instructions to see if they are different!  Not that it matters, but now I am interested.

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: Yup, the directions with the new stand are as you described.

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: So I guess they drew the picture wrong and added the text to save having to draw it again. Next thing, there'll be an urban myth about a 6-octave version of the C2 that sits on top of the stand... .

title: RE: Question about Nord C2 Organ Legs Stand?
post_content: Or, come to think of it, a C3 that has the octave of presets like a proper B3. That makes way more sense.

title: Midi problems with C1
post_content: Hi all,I have a custom made 25-note pedalboard. Its midi board is made by Midi Gadgets Boutique, a very professional company in Bulgaria.The pedals work perfectly with Yamaha, Casi and other branches but, for some reason, they just do not work properly with my C1.Sometimes it actually works and it's great, but then, on the same day, it stops working. I've tested everything (voltage, connectivity in midi cables, ALL is ok). There must be a problem in compatibility with the C1. Sometimes I plug and unplug the thing for an hour and then it starts working all of a sudden.Again: this only happens with the C1. No other keyboard behaves like this.I tried every possible protocol (device start up order, and so on). Nothing seems to work.Wrote to the technical support but they seem to be busy...Any help will be appreciated.

title: RE: Midi problems with C1
post_content: Does the pedal get the power from the MIDI connector? I think that Nords specify somewhere in the manuals not supporting power via MIDI (which was never the intention of the MIDI standard anyway). If that is the case, maybe you can add a power supply to your pedalboard.

title: Tweak C2D
post_content: Hi,Try this and tell me what do you think about it :drive : 4 ;  click : high level,  key bounce : on ; perc volume normal : low; perc volume soft : low ; leslie 145 ; rotary balance 60/40 ; horn speed : low.For me on a PA system and a subwoofer it's the best tweak.Kindly.Chris.

title: RE: Tweak C2D
post_content: ChrisBart wrote:Hi,Try this and tell me what do you think about it :drive : 4 ;  click : high level,  key bounce : on ; perc volume normal : low; perc volume soft : low ; leslie 145 ; rotary balance 60/40 ; horn speed : low.For me on a PA system and a subwoofer it's the best tweak.Thanks, I tried it on my C2. It sounds great through a PA System. Nice balance and leslie simulation.Is there a thread where we can share our preferred settings on the C2/C2D? That would be nice.

title: C2 organ sending velocity and receiving CC messages?
post_content: I just started using my iPad to trigger iLectric and iGrand sounds from the lower manual of my C2.  Using an iRig MIDI and it works and sounds great.   I also use an Ocean Beach DB-1 drawbar controller.  Which was working great in the past.  My big problem now is that in order to get the C2 to send velocity, I have to set Local Control (parameter 4 in the MIDI menu) to external device.  Apparently, when set to that mode, the C2 cannot receive the CC messages from the drawbars.  So I can't use both the Db1 and the external sounds together (unless I don't wan velocity sensitivity, but what good would that be?).Does anyone know a workaround for this?  I don't handstand why the C2 has to be in external mode to send velocity or why it won't receive CC messages in that mode.  Why can't Nord do a software update to fix this?ThanksDon

title: Nord C2D First play- Leslie Simulation or Leslie 145?
post_content: http://youtu.be/L7iCv0rtQcoJust received a Nord C2D combo organ.Great sound, my Hammond A100 and Leslie 145 in the background.Is the organ using the in built Rotary Effect or through my Leslie 145?I am VERY impressed with this 'clonewheel' from Nord. I've compared note for note with my Hammond A-100 and it's virtually identical, including leakage and crosstalk harmonics. The percussion is spot on once changed to long decay, and the key click to soft. For amp sim I use the close mic 122 with a 40/60 Bass-Horn balance.11 pin output to the Leslie 145, the sound is just the same, except physically moving air. Be sure to turn OFF the Rotary sim as to not 'double up' the effects!Using the TrekII 1147 connector kit, at this stage there's no STOP function for the leslie (as there is with my A-100 and Nord Rotary effect) so if you listen carefully, you'd hear that this recording is indeed, the Nord Leslie simulation!Amplified through HK Audio Nano 300 stereo pair (two subs and two tweeter stacks on each) the tone is identical to my Leslie 145.Just a quick improv recording using a RODE Stereo video mic in the middle of the room, behind me to the left (out of sight) straight to Macbook Pro Quicktime video movie.At 16kg compared to 130kg of my real chopped (portable-ized) A-100, this is going to be a real pleasure to take to gigs.

title: RE: Nord C2D First play- Leslie Simulation or Leslie 145?

title: First gigs with C2D
post_content: I'll probably be doing my first gigs as a keyboard player later this summer (I've done 2 gigs with keyboard before, but that was in high school about 12-13 years ago so it doesn't really count).First of all I wonder about the leslie simulator in C2D in a live situation. Is it passable to use it through the PA? I have access to a real leslie but we can't transport it with any of our cars so we'd have to rent one or something. I understand that this is highly subjective, but is the leslie sim good enough in a live context or should I try to convince my band mates that we need to bring the leslie?Secondly, if we don't bring the leslie, should I bring some kind of monitor amp to hear myself better? We will be playing at pretty small venues, but still, perhaps hearing myself will be difficult when the PA speakers are directed at the audience? What are your experiences and thoughts on this matter?

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: Hi JonasUsing the sim instead of a real Leslie will solve a lot of issues for you.  If the venue is large enough you would have to mic  it. If it is small, hten there is the space issue.  I use the sim all the time, bringing my Leslie is usually a luxury, and I find the sim is passable if not preferable. And yes you should have your own keyboard monitor system. Cheers Mike

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: Thank you for your helpful comment!I'm afraid I don't have a keyboard amp and neither can I afford it at the moment so I suppose a small transistor guitar amp will have to do.

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: Well I might be tempted to set everything up and trouble shoot it.  I have used my 3300 in small venues not going through to pa at all.  Very satisfying sound in that situation.  Not sure you would be happy using a small guitar amp.  Playing live without the Leslie, I use two powered Yamaha cabinets, and the keys are also going through the pa. Cheers Mike

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: If the sim was ever going to sound good, I think it would sound good through a stereo PA. Remember to use both outputs L and R into the left and right sides of the PA.And you could use the "headphone" outlet to drive your monitor or will a line come from the board to your monitor? A monitor line from the board can include other instruments/vocals too.

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: I've been playing Hammonds thru Leslies for years, and will tell you - The NORD SIM is not only acceptable, it's incredibly rockin'.    If you're gonna go to the well by asking your band mates for anything, don't waste the opportunity on lugging a Leslie to and from a gig.  Totally agree with Mooser - running L & R outputs to a stereo PA will sound fantastic.   When I play live, I've been using a 1000W powered speaker, and it screams.  At home, I have a couple old (separate) keyboard amps set up on either side of the room.  Wow!  talk about a round, washing, separated Leslie sound!   Sure, grab any small amp for your monitor.  Or, if the PA is sophisticated enough, you may be able to send the keyboard channel (only) to a speaker.G

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: As  Mr. Mastodon said:  'The Nord organ is mono, but the sim effect is stereo.'   Through a single amp, I'm not a big fan of sim.  But when two amps are used, the effect can really work.You know, for the price of a Leslie, you could upgrade the heck out of your PA system.

title: RE: First gigs with C2D
post_content: Wherever you go, always make sure you've got some way of monitoring yourself!  For me, it's a set of cheap headphones that I can wear if the going gets tough. that's not always going to work for you, but there's nothing worse than not being able to hear yourself.I mainly play small gigs too, usually with just an acoustic guitar player/singer. The guitar player has never once complained about not being able to hear himself, I guess in part because the guitar makes noise. You don't get any instant audible feedback like that from a keyboard.

title: RE: First gigs with C2D

title: RE: I'm probably buying a Hamichord.
post_content: the Hamichord is discontinued, so beware that you will not get support and updatesapart from that, the Hamichord is definitely heavier and bigger than the other two-manual clonewheels.It depends if you want to substitute the C2 or not.If you plan to keep the Hamichord at home and gig with the C2, it makes sense to me.If you plan to sell the C2 and do everything with the hamichord, it is still ok (even if definitely more cumbersome and a little outdated)So I don't think it would be "unwise", maybe just a little redundant (but then again, you said you need a backup board)

title: RE: I'm probably buying a Hamichord.
post_content: dlargent wrote:I decided that I need a back up keyboard, as I have gigged my Nord C2 five or six times a week for the last two years.If this means that you're thinking you need a backup because you've "overworking" or "wearing out" your C2, I really wouldn't worry about it. The Nords are built to take it, and that amount of gigging is well within your C2's capabilities. You'd be spending a lot of money and the chances that you'd ever need a backup organ are so remote that I think you would basically be wasting your money. Another option might be to buy a keyboard with additional capabilities (piano, synth, whatever) as well as a basic backup organ sound, which would expand what you could do as well as give you something you could use on a daily basis. This would give you more bang for your buck, and quite possibly be cheaper as well.

title: Clean up of 16' & 8' Bass Pedal Tones
post_content: So, have done a handful of gigs with my C2D, and am completely jazzed every time I turn it on.  Playing thru a QSC K12 powered speaker.  Plenty of volume, tons of bass, and great dynamic range.  I'm lovin' me some NORD!    (BTW - you may or may not agree with the basis of my comments - sound and like/dislikes are purely in the ear of the beholder, right?OK, here's the deal with the bass pedal sounds.   A standard B or A model Hammond typically has some high frequency tones in both 16' & 8' bass drawbars that I personally find awful.  I've been playing left hand bass as well as pedals forever, and want a very similar sound from both.  (LHB drawbar setting I like is 828000000) .  A long time ago, I learned of a very cool but beautifully simple wiring trick to eliminate the high freq's in both pedal drawbars.  Result is a deep, smooth, buttery, clean bass note, without those annoying high tones.   Here's the issue with the C2D - they have captured the B3 so perfectly, so closely, so spot on, so 'right down to the smallest detail leve' - that they also produce those awful high freq's in the pedal drawbars.  Arrrrrrrrrghhh!I've communciated this with Pablo who was more than willing to pass along the info to the R&D guys at NORD.  He informed me they have 3 B3's in their studio, against which they model the C2D's.  I offered to share the very simple B3 wiring trick, with a request of providing a download of the sound for my C2D.   Unfortunately, he informs me that they're not in the "modification" mode right now so, nutz!Anybody interested in that wiring trick?   5 minutes, promise!  4 snips, 2 twists, you're done.  Yer gonna love it!  (Again, unless you like the stock tones - like nails on a blackboard- just sayin')Also, which leslie pre amp kit would I use to connect my C2d to a 22h Leslie?     Thanks Everyone!

title: RE: Clean up of 16' & 8' Bass Pedal Tones
post_content: I haven't got a real B3 but would be interested to know what is this mysterious hack.Maybe you could post a small mp3 showing the result?

title: Sound samples of the C2/C2D rotary speaker simulations
post_content: Due to the discussion in the German Musiker Board Forum I recorded the different internal rotary speaker simulation of my Nord C2 - just for information or comparison.The parameters are:Nord C2 OS v2.0 (= sound of the C2D)Drawbars 888888888Chorus C3, Perc. off, Reverb off, Distortion 30%Leakage max.- sample a: Leslie-Sim A = 122 model- sample b: Leslie-Sim B = 122 model with close mics- sample c: Leslie-Sim C = 145 modelBass-Horn-Balance 50/50Leslie: starting fast, later slowhttps://soundcloud.com/spektralfarben

title: C2D Pipe organ sound to Stage 2
post_content: Hi Guys,Just a a quick one.. I have a stage two and need as an authentic a pipe organ as i can find. The pipe organ patches on theC2D seem great and my question is there any way of poatching them to the stage 2 ?I have no idea how to as im a bit of a noob to the nord...Many thanksMatt / Lutonbod

title: RE: C2D Pipe organ sound to Stage 2
post_content: Hi Matt,The C2D has a separate Baroque Pipe Organ Engine the Nord Stage 2 does not have, therefore there is a priori no way of porting patches using this engine to a NS2 (using .ns2p programs).The best way IMHO would be to use samples instead. While the Nord Sample Library does IIRC not contain any Pipe Organ Samples, you could even create them yourself, e.g., based on a C2D setting if you manage to get hold of one for the sampling. (Or you find someone owning a C2(D) nice enough to sample a patch for youAlternatively, you could try some samples other fellow members have contributed on this forum. Just do a in-page search (Strg+F) on the Nord Sample Collection website:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord_sample_collection.phpIt should give you around five samples you can try.Cheers!JohannesPS. This sub-forum is the right one for your post, so I removed the double posting (seeforum rule#4).

title: RE: C2D Pipe organ sound to Stage 2
post_content: thanks a Million johannes,Can you "briefly" advise me how to go about creating a patch from scrathch samples.. I'm quit happy to have a go at it but a little sketchy as to how...Many thanks for your swift respionse.. This forum is lifesavingMatt

title: RE: C2D Pipe organ sound to Stage 2
post_content: lutonbod wrote:advise me how to go about creating a patch from scrathch samplesNow you mean creating a patch from "scratch samples"? like record scratching? I have somewhere some samples for that.Or you mean creating a patch using samples "from scratch"? Maybe makes more sens in your context. In this case, have a look at this point in the Nord User FAQ:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-user- ... ple-editorFor quite a while we have been thinking of putting together a video of how to create samples for the Nords, but it's still TBD (hopefully finished by the end of october), so for the time being, reading the manual of the Sample Editor, and the link above might work as a start. First thing is to get a good sample to start with!!Cheers!

title: RE: C2D Pipe organ sound to Stage 2
post_content: Hi johannes,No, sorry for the misundersatnding.. I meant how do youy create a nord stage two patch .ns2p ? I cant seem to find how to create one ? I have some .wav files of my own and would like to crest some .ns2p Programs of my own ?Can you help me ? The manual doesnt make sense.. I'm assuming you can do this in the nord sample editor but it wont let me save or generta a .ns2p..ThanksMatt

title: RE: C2D Pipe organ sound to Stage 2
post_content: Hi,You first need to create a sample file. nsmp using the sample editor, then edit the patch using this sample in the Synth section and then you can save it as a program, and export it as n2sp file. But this n2sp file will NOT contain the sample itself, you always need it together with the sample, ie, the nsmp file.Hope this makes sense.

title: C1 output intermittant problem - sound level drops, stops
post_content: I use a C1 connected to a keyboard amp via a Morely volume pedal.I have recently had trouble where the sound output stops abruptly usually after 20 minutes of use.  This is happening with each use of theC1.I experienced this when using either the right out or left out output jacks on the C1.I've used two different amplifiers, several different sets of connector cables, and use new batteries in the Morely.Even turning the C1 off and on makes no change.Sometimes the volume level drops dramatically before stopping altogether.The only way to restart the sound output seems to be unplugging and reinserting the cable into the right out or left out jacks in the rearof the C1. Re-seating the cables in the volume pedal or amplifier has no effect.There is no apparent damage to the rear of the C1I have not used any type of contact cleaner in the output jacks.I had OS 1.06 and just upgraded to 1.12 and have not yet tested for any change.Pablo from Nord Technical Support wrote me to say he doesn't have an answer and I should take it to a repair shop.Has anyone experienced this besides me?

title: RE: C1 output intermittant problem - sound level drops, stops
post_content: Just for clarification purposes, I have an idea or two, but from 3000 miles away these things are best left to the judgment of the tech who has the instrument open on her or his bench.For the edification of the forum, I have seen 2-3 cases of Nord instruments with intermittent and unpredictable volume behavior in which the EMI-filter on the the control or swell pedal circuit has failed.  The failed component can cause the Nord to see phantom pedal movements (even where no pedal is connected) and respond accordingly.  I would advise your Portland tech to look there first.It remains curious to me that disconnecting and reconnecting audio cables from the back of the Nord would have any effect on the reported behavior, especially since disconnecting and reconnecting the other ends of the same cables seems to have no such effect.  Sometimes Muphy's Law plays funny tricks on people, making certain things appear to help when it's all coincidental.  Or perhaps it's significant...again, best left to the tech working on the unit.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: C1 output intermittant problem - sound level drops, stops
post_content: One thing you should try is to temporarily remove the Morley pedal and see what happens without it. At the very least that should indicate whether the problem is with the C1 or the Morley pedal. Your amp and cables are other possible things to look at.

title: RE: C2D Presets
post_content: Check the 'memory protect' function (System Menu #1)  Once 'memory protect is unlocked', it takes a double press of the "Store" key to store a change in program.

title: RE: C2D Presets
post_content: Press liveSelect preset a or bAdjust the soundHold shiftPress the preset you want to store to.

title: RE: C2D Presets
post_content: Hi MooserYour CV probably sounds close to my BC. They are really colorful organ. I would argue that they have richer sound than a B3. They usually leak more.The earlier Hammonds has the notes on the TG terminal strip in chromatic order. This required longer leads which increased leakege. Later they routed the shortes way which gave a less ordered sequence on the TG stripI have a switch piggybacked on my Lelsie so that can easily turn off the slow motors making my Leslie work in one speed mode. The change in sound goiung from dead stop is amazing. And as you say the long time to stop acts as a chorus. This why you see som gospel player flipping the swtich on an off quickly often. To keep the lower drum going slowly. And since the top rotor stops in acouple of seconds you realise how much the lower roter contributes to the 3d feeling in the sound. 80% at least.Contratulations to the TG

The effect from the bottom rotor is tremendous.And I need to settle the question of how the balanced-line Hammond pre-amp should be connected to the "single-ended" (unblanced input) Leslie.   "One G and ground?" or a matching transformer which converts  the balanced line to unbalanced?   Right now the organ is connected "one G and ground".  Nobody seems to have any definite answers on this.Not that I'm eager to mess around with the pre-amp connections on this one. That B+ voltage terrifies me!  And it's everywhere!  Always expecting it to jump out at me.Attached are a couple of samples. There's an EV instrument mike on the upper& lower rotor, and an AKG condenser mike in the room.  And as always, please forgive my clumsy playing. It's not easy with hooves, even if they're split.The Good Life, the bad playing.mp3Candy man.mp3Okay, this thing needs some reverb, badly. title: Weight of C2 in softcase
post_content: I have recently joined a band as an organ player. There is an old Hammond spinet organ (not sure which model) in the rehersal room, but there are too few keys per manual for my taste and the organ also lacks percussion. So I'm thinking about getting a C2 that I can get for a decent price, both for home practice and band rehersal. As I don't have a car I ride my bike to rehersals (about 20 minutes) so my question to you is if it seems doable to travel that distance by bike twice a week? Or is the organ plus case plus expression pedal too heavy to transport in that way?

title: RE: Weight of C2 in softcase
post_content: the C2 alone is 16 kgs and the softcase is very robust, it is not so light.I never weighed it, but I guess that organ+case+accessories will be well above 20 kilos.But more than the weight, the main point is that the case has no straps to carry it as a backpack, and anyway it would be too large and cumbersome.It is really nice to carry around by hand and the wheels make it perfect to use as a trolley (couldn't you use bus/metro?), but I can't imagine how you could transport it safely on a bike...

title: RE: Weight of C2 in softcase
post_content: What about a flight case for the C2 and a bicycle cart? The flight case would protect the C2 even if a car were to drive into your bicycle cart and the bicycle cart would also be handy for other stuff, like getting lots of groceries in one go or a trip to Ikea.If you subject those Nord softbags to lots of abuse (like airplane travel) they won't last that long and the protection they offer is much less than a real flight case. Of course, depending on the materials used and the way it is constructed, a flight case will easily weigh 8 to 15 kg and will be much more cumbersome than a softbag. Here's a blog from a guy who did a lot of traveling with a C1 in a softbag; I love the 'Excess bagage in Hong Kong' picture.http://hammond.no/?p=341Anyway, you could buy a pre-made bicycle cart for something like 100-250 euro (depending on what you get) and a flight case specifically made for the C2 would likely cost you about 125 to 200 euro, depending on the materials used (lighter = more expensive).Since you can't control the weather, whatever solution you come up with needs to be weatherproof enough to protect your Nord.Example flight case (several companies can build these for you, some even in red):This one is funny, I think.

title: RE: Weight of C2 in softcase
post_content: Hi JonasYou can definately forget about using the original Nord case for the C2D. It is a very nice case, BUT it weighs approx. the same as the organ itself.After learning thIs I quickly sold the case again and bought a (cheap) case at Thomann. They are selling some soft cases by their own name for very small money (approx. 250 DKK). However, in any case you should not try to move it by bicycle.The C2D is a very nice instrument. Sold my B3 back in 1990 and did not play until now, where I first bought a Hammond SK2. However, very quickly I realized, that for an old guy like me (55 years old) the user interface was far to complicated. After a few months the C2D was introduced and I quickly sold the SK2 and got a C2D, which is really a perfect instrument (also sounds better than the SK2)eGood luck with it (but take good care of it and please do not transport it on a bicycle). In this case you should buy a Nord Electro 3 or 4 (approx. 10 kg) with a Nord softcase for this, which it perfect for "back-pack" transportation.

title: Nord C2 vs C2D
post_content: HiWould it be accurate to say that the only material difference between the C2 (with the upgraded firmware) and the C2D is the physical drawbars?

title: RE: Nord C2 vs C2D
post_content: , "that one have to seriously consider if the price differential is worth it."Seems pretty simple to me. If you use the Vox, Farfisa or Pipe organ a lot, a C2 might be a better deal. The LED buttons work fine for those, and you still get the same B3 sound. If you want the ultimate convenience and realism in a B3 clone, it's the C2D with the 5 sets physical drawbars.The C2D (or the next version the C2D2? or C2D MkII?)  will become the standard organ, like the B3 was for so many years.  At the rate C2Ds are appearing on You-Tube videos, it can't be too overpriced. People are managing to get hold of them.However, I will make a generous offer, cause that's the way I am.  Anyone who is dissatisfied with their C2D should get in touch, and I will pay all costs associated (packing, shipping, insurance) with shipping it to me.  You'll never have to see it again.  As the song says "who could ask for anything else?"  Plus, I'll send you a video of me playing the great Rodgers-Hammerstein song "You'll Never Walk Again". (You know, the scene where he's injured on the merry-go-round thingy)  Sounds depressing to me, but if that's what you want, that's what you get. I aim to please.

title: RE: Nord C2 vs C2D
post_content: I got mine in early October 2011, just before the C2d came out. I agree with you about the C2 : it's way better,for the price, than any of us should expect.  I got it knowing that, if i only played at home, i would've been happy with a Roland VK77, a Korg BX3, or even a Viscount OB5. The C2 is light years beyond those, & , in time, will be superseded by numerous clones .  The differences, however, between the sound of the clones has become so subtle . How you PLAY the clone ( in this case, the C2 ) makes a huge difference . There are those players, however, who strive to hear the most intricate increases in authenticity, that i wonder how much they are interested in music for it's own sake.  What is fun is to go into forums & product reviews on clones going back to the mid-90's, & read about player's enthusiastic thoughts on the 'authenticity; of a roland vk7,viscount ob3 squared, or the Voce V3.  at some point, you have to accept the axe you have & concentrate on the MUSIC>

title: RE: Tried a B3 the other day - no wow feeling this time
post_content: I was considering a set of the new Ocean Beach Drawbars to my C-2, but reports are that in spite of being a matching shade of red, and sized to fit right on top of a C1 or 2, the drawbar action is cheap-feeling, and not satisfying to use.  But I'm watching for the new version, to see if that is improved.But yes, one-piece, 39 lbs. full five sets drawbars, the refined features and effects, the extra organs, the price, the sound, the feel: the C2D will be the standard, for years to come.And yes, playing a well-maintained or rebuilt Hammond is like nothing else. Playing one on it's last legs (and last few micro-farads in the power-supply caps) is painful.   Btw, whatever is wrong with a Hammond will show up within five minutes of my starting to play.  Not to mention the number of people (it's true, happens all the time)  who don't know what exactly, the percussion and\or vibrato/chorus is supposed to do, so don't know when it's broken.  I have, on more than three occasions, ran into Hammond/Leslie ownersthat didn't know the Leslie rotors have to turn on and off with an easily accessed switch! (or thought lower-manual foldback was a fault which needed fixing)But I'd better stop, or I'll start sobbing again.  Did I tell you about the guy who stood right in front of me (just out of strangle-range) and told me about taking a nice 15" speaker out of a 122 Leslie, andthrowing the rest in a dumpster?Now I am crying again. Ever see what happens to a Hammond around here (NW US) if it's shoved into a basement for years?  You can almost see the "Hammond-hairs" growing, and hear the case rotting, and the mice chewing, and the owner is standing there, beaming, saying "I inherited it from my Mom, and I haven't touched it, so it's all vintage!" Grrrr...sob.... "Are you saying that's a torn speaker and not overdrive, I thought it was supposed to sound like that..."And shall we start talking about "Hammond Techs" now?  Nah, I'll just go have a Prussic acid cocktail.   (Thank the Lord there are still a few knowledgable and efficient techs left, but they ain't cheap, nor should they be)

title: RE: Tried a B3 the other day - no wow feeling this time
post_content: New member, weighing in here.  I've owned a few B3's over the years.  My first was purchased new around 1970.  Moved it around the country for about 20 yrs, before selling it.   Now 40 yrs later, and after playing synths and a Korg CX3 for a long time, I decided to get my 'bucket list' B3.  Unintentionally, I wound up with 2 of them.   Found a "beater" and a "mint condition" around the same time so, while I was in the B3 frenzy mode, I got them both.   Here's the kicker -  Of course not needing 2 B's, I decided to upgrade from my Korg CX3 sooooooo,  I made an even Steven trade from a dealer for a new C2D.   Deal wise, we both won, and I still now have my prize B to jam at home with.    And last comment - there are many, repeat many fantastic features about the C2D, and I love having and playing it.  However - there will never, ever, be anything like sitting at a well maintained B3, and screaming it through a fat Leslie.   Just my $.025.

post_content: "I agree. I have 1937 BC than sounds great. And a C2d to haul around. I love both. For different reasons."Yes, but you are lucky to live in a very liberal country, where that kind of thing is accepted.  Over here, it would probably lead to bloodshed, if not a very nasty divorce.You should hear what goes on in my studio between the A-100 and the C2. Frankly, I had no idea Swedish was such a profanity-rich language, but then again, coming from Chicago gives one a rich vocabulary of pejoratives, too.  Luckily, the recorder was running when I brought the C2 home:A-100:  OMG, what is this? (Starts playing "Send in the Clones")C2:  Careful, there, ol' timer, don't blow your last capacitor!A-100:  Listen, lightweight, it took 3 guys to carry me down here!C2:  Hmmm, I thought six was the minimum number of pallbearers...A-100:  Why should I answer you? You're just going to blow away with the next light breeze.C2: Whatsamatter, Grandpa, your key-contacts getting a little erratic? Too many spurious harmonics?A-100: At least I have 9 key-contacts!  And you call those "drawbuttons"? I have real drawbars!And that was just the first few minutes, and then it got really personal, and in my opinion, needlessly tendentious and invidious.  I ended up threatening to pull plugs.I've got one whining "You never take me anywhere, are you ashamed of me because I'm heavy?" and one yelling: "All you do is take me around to show off to your friends, and then leave me in the case at home, and play her!"  I couldn't take it.Then the C2D came out, and the A-100 was just being cruel about it, so I explained to the A-100 that all the new Hammond-Suzukis were, in fact, clones.  Things are better now, they realise they've got no-one but each other, so they have to learn to get along. But neither of them will ever forgive me for my infidelity.

title: C2D in mono?
post_content: Is it possible to use the C2D in mono?

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Have you tried just using one channel?

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: I think it is basically a "mono" instrument. The signal for both the left and right channel are identical, and either can be used.  I do believe the only time they are different is when the Leslie sim is engaged.  At that time the left and right represent mikes on both sides of a Leslie.  Would there be any point to summing them down to one channel if the organ is being played through only one amp?This is one, exactly what the deal is with the two outputs, and the Leslie sim, is something Mr. Mastodon would know, and maybe he'll tell us.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: It is not a mono instrument.Left and right are not identical. It is a simualtion of a stero miked Lelsie.But if you use one channel you do not loose anything but the stereo spread effekt.It would be the same as muting on channel on the mixer board and setting the pan tonthe middle

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Hi Mooser/flmc59,Please, please, no "Mr." needed; Pablo works just fine.The audio outputs are parallel mono until rotary speaker is engaged, after which things do start to diverge in the stereo field.As a matter of perspective, it may be useful to recall that 1) the tonewheel organ being modeled is, in fact, a mono instrument, and 2) that in many live situations the house mixer does not have the luxury of an unlimited number of audio input channels and the horn rotor is not stereo-mic'd.  Taking only one side of the organ's audio output would essentially be equivalent to that.In a studio production environment I would guess that most producers would want to take advantage of using a stereo feed in most instances.  For live work...sometimes it's less practical to run stereo in club settings or small rooms.  Certainly stereo is juicier and I always try to go that way when I can, but only in mains, not stage monitor.The thing to avoid in ALL situations is to attempt to convert the stereo output to mono via a "Y" cable.  This will almost invariably result in phase cancellation weirdness which will make everything sound simply awful.  Then again, some folks really like simply awful...Pablo

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Pablo, while we're on the subject of outputs on Nord organs, would you tell us about the intended use of the  "high-level" 1/4" output next to the 11-pin rotory speaker plug?Should this output only be used to drive Leslie amplifiers which were designed to be driven off a console speaker output, or can it  be used to drive a line-level input power amp?Thanks.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: You can use it for amps as well.But remember that i packs a good umph. 3,5 v as compared to 1v line level.No rotor sumulation available on this jack

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: If it is to high just tuen down the master or build an attenuator pad.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: It is possible, but not recommended.  Best-case scenario, the lop-sided gain structure created by doing this will likely reduce the quality of tone.  Worst-case scenario, it will damage the circuitry of the line level amp input.  There is no good reason for wanting to do this.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: I have used the high out to feed my MotionSound with no problems.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Thanks for the information, Pablo. Thanks for the reminder about summing the channels and Leslie sim. As a matter of fact, I was doing that with an early Hammond-Suzuki (SM2000) I use at practice (it was $20) because it seemed to cut down on noise and hum. No wonder the Leslie sim sounds so wierd! I mean, it was an early version, but still...I use the high-level 1/4 to feed my Leslie 145, which is equipped with a 1/4 jack and powered by its own cord.The regular output of the C2 is hot enough, I would think, and better still, dead silent.Pablo, could I ask one more question?  Well, I'm gonna.  Is the "master level" control on the C2 a digital or analog control?  On a digital control (I hope I got this right) below a certain point (usually about %40-50) the number of digital bits skipped (to lower volume) starts to affect the analog output sound, making it thinner. Therefore, it's best to set the amplifier gain controls so the "master level" control on the organ can be open at least to 50% for normal volume range.Also, does the volume controller circuit on the Nord organ (worked by the swell pedal)  control both volume and tone in emulation of the Hammond variable-capacitor swell pedal?  If so, this will effect how one sets both the master level and the volume pedal.Any light you could shed on these aspects would help me  in getting the best out of my C2.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: The swell pedal cuts harder in the mids than the highs and lows.So if you turn up the master and backs of on the swell you get more highs and lows.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: The High Level output is intended to feed a popular brand of rotary speaker.  The Motionsound, having been designed to replicate this function may be equivalent -- I don't know the detail of the MotionSound unit.  "Normal" amps are not designed for that high level input however.  I know of at least one instance where someone with a Roland KB amp (the 60?) experienced serious distortion problems from having used the high level output.  When repatched to the regular outs, the amp's bad behavior persisted.  Because the instrument performed flawlessly via headphones, it was assumed in that case that the amp had sustained damage from the high level output.  The whole thing could have been a coincidence arising from a lemon amp, but...

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: As far as I know, (and I've got the instructions right here in front of me) the Motion Sound Pro3x has a  "Input design range" of  "1 volt to 4 volts P-P (5 volts maximum)  However, the "Input Impedance" is "100k ohms".   To me, this looks like a line level device, but it can stand quite a hot input signal. I don't think it's designed to be driven by a low-impedance speaker source, but it may be possible.If am using my Pro-3x with my A-100, I take a balanced line from the pre-amp (BOTH "G"s and ground) and send it through a DI box (a "REAMP" in this case) which converts it to an unbalanced signal. I have never had any luck using "One G and ground" but that's supposed to work. For my C-2 I use the regular Left or Right output, and I think, whatever the final volume, the organ sounds best if the master level control is set at least %50.  And there is no background noise, nada! at any volume setting from the Nord. Dead silent!  Never heard anything like it, actually. Wish I could say the same for the Pro-3X, but who would I say it to? They's gone.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Hi Mooser,Sometimes us tech-heads can get a little lost/wrapped up in tech specs and manuals and lost sight of what it's all about...and no, the Hokey Pokey is NOT what it's all about.You did mention it in your post though: your ears.  The high level input is designed precisely for such units as your 145, yet your ears tell you (if I read you correctly) that you prefer the sound of the C2's "regular" output going to your 145.  I don't think you're wrong to trust your ears in almost all cases.Yes, the swell pedal circuit operates as a swell pedal and not a simple volume pedal, just as it does on that original tonewheel organ which it is modeling.  Surely you would expect no less from Nord and your C2.The Master Level control is an analog one.  The "dead give-away" is that fact that there is no midi cc # associated with it.  If it were dig, there almost certainly would be.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Thanks for all your responses Pablo. I guess I wasn't clear: I use one of the the regular outputs for my Motion Sound and the hi-energy 1/4 out-put feeds the Leslie, and is very convenient for that.  I've never tried using the hi-energy plug to feed a line level device like the Motion Sound, but if those specs are right, it could take it. title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: Hi Howard.The upper manual in pipe mode is a softer set of pipes. This is quite common for the type organ that was used.The swell pesal only affects the upper manual (Swell) and controls a set of horisontal wooden "Blinders" that open or shut when the swell pedal is pressed. This is volume is controlled for the swell on a pipe.As you add voices in the lower manual you need to press the swell pedal to max in order for the softer pipes to have any chance at all.If you pull all the great they will dominate compared to all swells

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: I know I'm digging up an old thread, but I hope this information is useful to someone:As others have already said, when the Leslie sim is engaged you no longer have the same information on both channels.  When I went from playing stereo to mono recently due to space considerations, I found that going out of only one channel didn't work - when the "Leslie" would spin away from whatever side I was using, I would lose the sound.  (Obviously I mean the Leslie sim, and spinning away from the virtual mics.  Anywho...)  I needed a way to properly sum these two channels so I could get 100% of the sound information, even if it was compromised by not being run in stereo.I own a Mackie 1202-VLZ mixer, so I sent an email to Mackie to see what they would do; they told me to run the Nord's R and L outputs into channels 1 and 2 (NOT the stereo channels, but I'm not sure why) and turn the pan controls straight up on each channel.  I think of it this way:  The mixer is treating each output of the Nord as a separate instrument, much like if I had run a guitar and a bass on those channels.At this point, you just take your pick as to which mixer output you wish to use - both R and L are exactly the same.  I've found this is really awesome, as I can run a line elsewhere that is an exact copy of what I'm listening to should the need arise.  And for the mad scientists out there, one could have some fun with Aux effects, although that all should happen prior to the Leslie effect...but I digress.Summary:Run Nord R output into mixer channel 1Run Nord L output into mixer channel 2Set mixer channel 1 and 2 pansstraight up 12 o'clockNow mixer R and L outputs have a mirrored copy of your audio; pick one and use it.Play Giant Steps, amaze your friends.Disclaimer:  This may be common knowledge to others, so my apologies if I'm spouting stuff that everyone else knows.  I sure didn't!Thanks,Josh

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: "Was wondering how you would rate the sound difference between your Motion Sound unit, and the Nord Simulated (through a non Leslie amp?Thanks"The Motion Sound is not as sweet-sounding as a Leslie, but to me it's better than sim. And my Pro3x is half sim, the top horn is real, but the bottom baffle (800Hz and down) is sim, and goes through whatever amp is adequate I've never tried playing my C2 through two separated amps, which might make the sim better, since it is a stereo effect. Through a single keyboard amp, the sim doesn't do much for me.And a real rotating horn is lots more fun. Can't get away from that.

title: RE: C2D in mono?
post_content: If you can find a Pro 3tm and a low pro bottom rotor then you have a nice systen that sounds quite good. Ac145 Leslie is better but my Motionsound rig is very portable.In a room two rotors upper lower will always give a wider sound than two static speakers with at simulation.There is a fixed radiation pattern in a PA compared to 360 rotating speakers.

title: C2 error!  Should I worry??
post_content: I have a C2 with 2.0 operating system.  Today I had it at my teacher's studio, and in the middle of the lesson, it freaked out.  Three or four shrill notes rang out and wouldn't stop until I pressed the panic button.Then about a minute later, the display jumped to program 108 and a few different notes rang out, and continued to ring until I played the corresponding note on the keyboard.I tried turning it off and back on, but the same thing happened again in about a minute.Maddeningly, when I brought the C2 home and played it, the problem didn't happen again.Does anybody know what could be wrong?  Maybe the problem was a fluke, but I'll start to worry if it ever happens again...

title: RE: C2 error!  Should I worry??
post_content: If it works fine at your house then it may be something at the teachers house that causes it.To what was the C2 connected at the teachers house?Are there any transmitting radio devices - etc.

title: RE: C2 error!  Should I worry??
post_content: We had it connected to a small Yamaha mixer with a quarter-inch cable. The power cable was plugged in to a power strip, which was also powering the mixer and a kurzweil electric piano. In addition, I have a Roland expression pedal and the nord half-moon switch attached.I left the C-2 on all night last night at my house And everything was fine.

title: RE: C2 error!  Should I worry??
post_content: "the display jumped to program 108"The only C2 trouble I have had is an instability in the program selectors too. They can jump around, and jump programs instead of moving one-per-press unless held. I would tend to think it might be a weakness in the button-switches, as it would take, I would think, one hell of an outside interference to get to those switches.I would think that the inadvertent program-switching produced the 'hung' notes. There are some 'hangs' on the C2. If you switch programs or certain switches while pedals are depressed, they can 'hang'.

title: Possible Leslie 2101mk2 setup
post_content: Hello friends,For a portable Leslie for restaurant jazz gigs, and the occasional jam session at the bar, I'm thinking about the 2101mk2.I'm specifically wondering if someone has tried option #2 below? No problem?Here's how I think I'll set it up:1) normally, 2101mk2 alone2) If it is gutless in the bass, stack it on top of a non-Leslie sub-woofer3) If a jam session becomes a volume contest, mic everything to the house PA.4) If one day I decide to play rhodes/piano etc, put a nice powered speaker on top of my sub-woofer (Mackie SRM350v2, Yamaha MSR250 etc.)I think the benefits of this setup are relative affordability, versatility, and low footprint.

title: RE: Possible Leslie 2101mk2 setup
post_content: Mooser wrote:A good woofer, even multiple woofers, yes, but is a sub-woofer an advantage?Note: I only have headphones right now, so this is all theory...I'm new to this organ, but I think it can produce frequencies down to 32.692 Hz. This is why I'm interested in a subwoofer. From my research, some woofers can produce this sound, but not with a flat frequency response. So your mid-range notes will sound way louder than your bass notes.I found this tonewheel chart that explains the frequencies generated by Hammond tonewheels:http://www.goodeveca.net/RotorOrgan/ToneWheelSpec.htmlThis chart lists the lowest frequency as 32.692 Hz.To confirm, I did an experiment where I found the lowest frequency by counting down from A440.I started with a reference tone:Note: we can uncomplicate the experiment by using only the FUND (3rd from left or 4') drawbar. Then we don't have to think about foldback.Using only the FUND drawbar, I find 440 Hz at the 3rd A from the left. The 2nd A is 220 Hz, and the 1st A is 110 Hz. But if you activate the Bass Pedal button and use only the SUB drawbar, you can get one octave lower, 55 Hz (I don't have pedals yet).So the lowest A on the organ is 55 Hz, and referencing the tonewheel chart, the C below that is 32.7 Hz.If you follow my steps, do you get the same answer?My goal is for the whole organ to sound at apparently equal volume, although I'm questioning everything nowI just discovered a Motion Sound subwoofer, the SW-15. I assume this is designed for organ playing, but the manual says it is 40 Hz - 300 Hz. Maybe it would do the job?

Mixing and matching cabinets will always be a trial and error situation though.

title: RE: Possible Leslie 2101mk2 setup
post_content: "Lowest C pedal is ~32 hz manual ~64 hz."You know what gets me?  Why on earth did Hammond not include 'pedal sustain' on the console models?  All the spinets had it!  Why not put it on the 25 pedal models, and make it much easier to play a running bass with the left foot?  Every other electric-electronic organ had some kind of pedal sustain.  But not the Hammond consoles.Why is that? It'd be a definite advantage, and there's always an "off" option if the player doesn't like it.    Whatever the method used to produce the sustain, why couldn't it be used on the console (full size B3) models?If this is a question that should not be asked, I apologise, but I've wondered about it since, oh, 1965 or so.  I remember being very surprised when I found out none of the rockers an the console was pedal sustain. I assumed it was there.Yes, 'pedal sustain' doesn't  work when using the pedals to produce thump on LH bass but that technique hadn't even come along yet,  and there's always the off switch.  All the aftermarket 'string bass' or 'synth bass' attachments for a Hammond pedals had sustain.
