post_content: Mooser wrote:this one is bi-amped with a gazillion watts.Having sat right in front of it, I would say this is a scientifically valid statement.Mooser wrote:the mystery of no pedal sustain on Hammond consoles remains unsolvedWhat do you mean by pedal sustain? A setting to lengthen the duration of pedal notes after releasing the pedal? Or are you talking about a piano style sustain pedal?

title: RE: Possible Leslie 2101mk2 setup
post_content: "A setting to lengthen the duration of pedal notes after releasing the pedal?"Yes, exactly. "pedal sustain" makes it much easier to play a bassline with one foot, the other foot being pretty much trapped on the swell pedal."pedal sustain" and "pluck" is what the "Synth bass" on the C2-C2D gives. The "sustain" gives you time to move your foot a third or fourth, and eliminates most heel-toe moves. Every spinet, from every maker, had it. All console size (2x61+25-32 peds) organs had it (except, I think for a few which were supposed to be "classical")  But the Hammond console models ( A-B BV B3 etc.)  didn't.  I've always wondered why.Now, as far as I can see, you can't use "synth bass" for the mixed LH-and-pedal bass style, the sound of the LM and pedals have to sort of match. But for playing a pedal only bassline, and playing chords with the LH, pedal sustain can be very useful.But again, the weird part it, all the spinets (the M models and later L models) had it for their one-octave pedalboards, but it wasn't put on the 25 pedal models.  Why? running bass with the foot is expounded in all the Hammond instruction books, they were well aware the organ was used for popular music.The only answer I ever got, from an old-line  Hammond tech who worked at Puget Sound Organ, was that pedal sustain required a relay for each pedal (?) and was cost-prohibitive on the console.  But I'm not sure that's right, or that I understood it right. Where are the pedal sustain relays (should be 12, I guess) on the spinets?  Very likely I didn't understand him properly. "flmc" might be the guy to clear this up, as he knows the spinets very well.However, I do believe it showed up again in Hammond's post tone-wheel, pre-Suzuki era. But I don't like to think about those models, I just get depressed.Sorry for going on about it, but it's puzzled me for oh, about 45 years since I was 15.  The first time I got close to a Hammond B3 (at my organ teacher's home, I believe) I wassurethere was a pedal sustain rocker, but I just didn't know where it was. Actually had a recurring dream about it, Never could figure it out.A 3300 Keybduo and pedals? Wow, what a rig!

title: Pipe setting on C2d
post_content: Just a quick question abut the pipe organ mode. If I want to play the pipe settings do I need to use two speakers one left and one right?  And I'm not sure that I know how to use couplers,what they do?  If anyone could give me the 5 minute  lesson that would be most helpful.  I am going to try and use this C2d in my Masonic Lodge as our big old Conn theater organ is acting up and might need to beaut to sleep.  Thanks Howard.

title: RE: Pipe setting on C2d
post_content: Sure, it'll sound better in stereo.  I do believe the sample-based pipe organ is stereo.  Couplers couple the stops from one manual to the keys of another manual. If the coupler has a number after it (4' or 16')  that means the manuals are coupled, but one octave higher (4') or lower (16')  Try them!At a moderate volume. And remember, since the C2D pipe organ is modeled pretty authentically, the swell pedal only works for the swell manual, and the great manual is generally much louder than the swell until the pedal is full open or stops from great are  coupled to it.  The great manual and pedals are full open all the time, so you may have to re-adjust the master volume.  There's a full section on the pipe organ in the manual.And try the numbered programs for pipe organ settings, as they wll have effects in them. Or you can set it up from the panels.  And I believe there some kind of "bottom-note-of-chord-gets pedal"  feature on the lower manual, and the lower manual can be split in the Pipe Organ mode, too.I hope that helps. No internal sim on Pipe Organ mode, and it doesn't sound very good, to me, played through a leslie.

title: RE: Pipe setting on C2d
post_content: Just to add a little to Mooser's comments.  The simulated pedal function (which adds any selected pedal stop to the bottom note you play on the lower "Great" manual) can be accessed by turning on the "Ped/Gr Low" control.  (That is what it is called on the C2; I presume it is the same on the C2D).  The "Sub Octave " couplers (Swell16  /  SW16/GR) allow you to play whatever stops you have selected at the octave below.  So, if you have the 8' Oboe on the Swell & couple this to the Great with the SW16/GR, it will sound as a 16' Oboe.  Unlike most pipe organs, though, I have been told that this effect goes right down to the bottom note.  Pipe organs generally do not have the extra octave of pipes below the indicated footage, so the effect runs out at tenor C.  Just a clarification (unless I am wrong - "What again?").  You normally cannot couple stops FROM the Great manual TO the Swell (ie play the Great Flute on the Swell manual).  Oh, and Mooser is right that playing the Pipe Organ through a Leslie sounds horrible.  Just look online for demos & you will hear some truly appaling things!  Properly amped, though, I am sure the C2D will sound wonderful.

title: C2 Coupler & pre-set queries
post_content: Hi,First post here, as I am planning / hoping (if SWMBO agrees!) to buy a C2.  I do not need the physical drawbars as the majority of the playing will be on the pipe organ & I can just get by with the other samples.  I have downloaded the manul & all seems to fit the bill, but I have a few queries which I hope you kind owners may be able to answer.1) Am I correct in assuming that the presets are: a) treated as 6 Generals (rather than 3-per-manual divisionals) when in pipe-organ mode &; b) adjustable.  I currently use a Roland C180 on which I can adjust the 4 presets very simply.2) When the "Sw16" is enabled, does it actually extend the sub-octave to the bottom of the keyboard?  I am currently doing some re-wiring on a pipe organ to give this, but I know that, as a rule, there are no extra pipes.  (Why not?  Even a single additional 3-octave rank, starting at 16'' & called off at the relevant pitch would be better than the bass fading out.  Grrrr!)3) Similar to Q2, does the same apply to the "Sw16-Gt"?  It would be good to underpin the Gt chorus with a 16' Oboe, but not much point if it cuts off at Tenor C.4) If you have the "Sw16" / "Sw4" enabled, does this pull through if you draw "Sw-Gt"?  It would seem a wasted opportunity to have Sw4 available only on the Swell, as you would never really achieve "Full Organ".  (Again, on the pipe organ project, if I draw Sw-Gt & Sw Sub / Sw Octave it DOES pull through, but I will be adding a dedicated Sw Sub-Gt for flexibillity.)BTW - unlike some contributors in the other posts, I personally would rather have the Swell as the overall loudest division.  That way, you can have it swell up through the Gt to crown off the sound, but also drop it to below the Gt level for accompaniment.  I regularly play a digital organ with 10 Gt stops & 5 Sw stops &, to be honest, there is little point in opening the Sw as it makes negligible difference.  (OK, first post & already started an argument!)Very many thanks in advance for your collective time.

title: RE: C2 Coupler & pre-set queries
post_content: Hello,These answers are all based on the most recent update for C2 2.00 the reason I note this is that it seems there were some revisions done to the coupling in other versions of the firmware.1. Presets are treated as general presets (Great, Swell, Pedal all together)2. Yes, when Sw16 is triggered the swell keyboard sounds at both 8' and 16' pitches all the way to the bottom of the keyboard3. Yes4. Unfortunately there is no pull through to either the great or the pedal (with some midi magic this might be possible) in the current firmware the 16' and 4' swell couplers only plays on the Swell keyboard.Interesting note, while designing a AGO 32 note pedalboard for my nord C2 I discovered that 32' pitches were available for the pedal stops (Sub/fagot 16). This makes me suspect that the pipe organ "samples" do have some digital patch capabilities beyond the standard settings.The C2 is a fantastic option for a practice pipe organ, its biggest downfall is the relative inflexibility and lack of stops (just basic flutes, strings, diapason, and reed) but when you compare the "coupling" options to something like the Hammond SK series (have not personally played) it gets the job done for a fraction of the price and more importantly the weight of an traditional electric instrument.

title: RE: C2 Coupler & pre-set queries
post_content: Many thanks vanderhill22,That is (mostly!) what I wanted to hear.  I guess there is a logic to having a Sw16-Gt coupler if the Sw16 / Sw-Gt combination does not pull through, but it does seem a shame to not have the Sw4 pull through.  Ah well, it is certainly better than what I have at present & may, of course, be changed in the future.  (Hmmm ...plans email campaign to Nord!)  Sorry to ask again but I presume the presets are adjustable quickly?  On the Roland, it is simply set up the registration (or add / subtract from the current preset combination), hold "Set" & the preset piston you want & you are done.  Is it as easy on the Nord?  I often adjust these between hymns to reflect the feeling of the verses, so it would be useful not to require major button-pressing.I have only really done the basics with MIDI, so how did you discover the 32' options & are they working in real-time?  I often use the Roland at the moment for weddings at a large local former school chapel with no pipe organ & a 32'reed would sound stunning there - as long as I do not need to re-program & faff about.  If it is a real-time option, I guess I could play with just the 8' (down an octave), then add the 16' (32') when required???As to the stops, I guess it is a question of how many could be added.  Software-wise, they could include thousands for peanuts, but physically operating them would be the sticking point.  Suppose it is just a case of working within the limitations.Last question: I have read on one forum about the usual digital-organ issue of using too many stops / muddying the sound.  I always avoid "full" organ on the Roland, but how well does the Nord do in this respect?Best wishes.

title: RE: C2 Coupler & pre-set queries
post_content: Let me answer the preset question first, the short answer being yes changes are instant. I spent a lot of time with this during my project where I designed toe studs to trigger the presets (http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-c1-c2 ... t4055.html). Let me explain further.The presets are instantly adjustable within each program. Each program has 6 general presets available for pipe organ so if I add or subtract a stop for preset "1" it will instantly save this and recall each time I select that preset while I am still in that program. If I want to move to another program I will need to save the program to preserve these new settings (only takes 1 button to save). I can also save on the fly by using the 2 "live" banks a very useful setting that nord has implemented in most of its keyboards. The 6 general presets act just like a real organ piston, you get instant switching of the registration with no holdover. I desired the toe stud set up since the nord does not have the preset buttons close enough to do registration changes while still having that ability to play with two hands on deck (like with thumb pistons, toe pistons).I used highlyliquid's MIDI CPU for the pedalboard which really gives you limitless options for midi projects but it does take some DIY effort (lots of faffing about). Again I refer you to the referenced post and the link I give there. The reason I discovered the 32' pitch was I accidentally programmed the pedals to trigger the pedal stops an octave lower than desired for the 16' pitch. It sounded pretty close to a real 32' pitch for the sub-bass patch and reed but I didn't investigate further. Pretty cool thoughAdding stops via midi control is an interesting project to consider. Again the forums on highlyliquid have lots of Haptwork organ designers building very cool things and should inspire...Not having a ton of experience in digital pipe organs I can't speak on much authority in this regartd. I would say IMHO that the C2's full organ sound is still pretty impressive given it is "sample" based (again just speculation). The ability to adjust EQ helps, I never use the tremulant feature (you get 6 different types) and rarely have full organ dialed in but I won't be embarrassed by it if push came to shove.

title: RE: C2 Coupler & pre-set queries
post_content: Many thanks again,I had seen the highlyliquid post, but not realised the connection.  Looks like a good setup & will, no doubt, get the best from the C2.  At the moment I have just a one-octave set of pedals so it may be an idea to set these up with the MIDICPU so that the keyboard/pedal coupler plays as is on the manuals, but the pedals play the sub octave.  (As long as I don't expect my pipe organ to do the same lol.)I may have not explained the "additional stops" bit correctly.  I was referring to your comment about the "relative inflexibility and lack of stops ".  Many digital organs include additional samples - either complete alternatives or some floating stops.  Even the Roland has a nod in this direction with a "Brightness" button, which certainly perks up the Fifteenth, but affects the otherwise rather smooth Flutes by adding a little chiff / articulation.  It only takes a little extra ROM for this, but the problem comes with recalling them real-time for use.  Switching from one set to another on a Johannus organ I played regularly left about 3 seconds of silence whilst the new set was loaded, so no use during a piece, or even between verses, but OK if planned for & loaded before playing.  But, you still physically need a control of some description to select (a combination of button-presses maybe).  Probably too late to expect the C2 to get a dedicated second set of samples, but if they do think about it for the C2D, maybe it will work on the C2 with a firmware upgrade, if there is enough memory available.I guess that, for "Full Organ", it is a case of getting the best sound you can.  When I started paying at the local Crematorium, I spent a good hour in the chapel listening to various combinations before deciding what was sensible to include & what had no positive value on the six presets.  The upshot of this was that "Full" organ is only about 2/3 of what is available, 'cos the rest do not really add anything to the volume, but just fog up the sound.Anyway, ramble over & my thanks again for your advice.

title: Using C2 with sequencer
post_content: My problem is a very basic one and I'm sure I'm missing something but can't seem to find an answer on here. I'm trying to record the two manuals on the C2 separately into 2 midi tracks on my sequencer. At the moment all the information from upper and lower keyboards is being recorded to both tracks. How do I change the settings so I transmit the upper manual to say track one in the sequencer and the lower manual to track 2? The C2 midi settings are set to 1.1 and 2.2. Are these midi 'out' channels or midi 'ins'. I use Cubase 6.5.Cheers,Steve Jeffries

title: RE: Using C2 with sequencer
post_content: Hi,I think, it is a problems of the track MIDI-settings in Cubase.I am using my C2 on the MIDI channels 11 (upper) and 12 (lower). These are "out" and "in" channels I suppose. I don't know how to set-up in Cubase but in my Samplitude Music Studio MX I can set for each track:- MIDI-IN device (= C2) and MIDI-IN channel ("all" or a certain channel 1...16)- MIDI-OUT device and MIDI-OUT channel ("all" or a certain channel 1...16).It is import to set the tracks ondifferentMIDI channels, not to "all". It should work.So, to record the both manuals separately you have to set track 1 (upper) to MIDI-In on channel 1 and track 2 (lower) to MIDI-In on channel 2.For the correct playback also the MIDI-OUTs must be set to 1 and 2. Perhaps you have to check again the track-specific MIDI settings.You could test the "MIDI-IN behaviour" e.g. with MIDIOX freeware.I hope you will have success!

title: RE: Using C2 with sequencer
post_content: Yes thanks, there's a separate 'input transformer' plugin in Cubase you have to set up on each midi channel. Works but not as elegant as Samplitude!Cheers,Steve

title: Speakeasy C2D outputs
post_content: I have a Speakeasy vintage preamp which I control my 122 with. However the leslie jack socket output on the C2D seems to be quite high level to go into that preamp. Probably because it was meant to go straight into a leslie that has jack inputs and not another preamp stage.Can I defeat the onboard leslie and use the other main outputs?

title: RE: Speakeasy C2D outputs
post_content: "Can I defeat the onboard leslie and use the other main outputs?"Does your C2D have the optional  "Speaker Model" controls? If it does turn the "Speaker Model" control to "off" (No light shows)  Did you get the optional, extra-cost instruction book with the organ?  If not, I believe they can be ordered from Nord.Yup, I'm being sarcastic. You know why? Cause I don't have a 122 or a Speakeasy vintage pre-amp, that's why, and I'm jealous.  I have to pay a friend to wave a tweeter around over his head when I play. And he never gets the chorale speed right.Yes, the high level 1/4 is a couple-volt level, low impedance (gosh darn it, what the hell, exactly, is "impedance"?   Is it like "pass interference", which is what usually happened when I put my hand on my date's leg?) like the out-put from an amplifier, and the main outs are the  half-volt higher-impedance signal to go to the preamp. line level, they call it.  Leslie sim should be turned off. Remember, it is possible to have Leslie "amp model" on with no sim rotation.  Turn it off.

title: RE: Speakeasy C2D outputs
post_content: I also think going through a good DI box would get the signal to an appropriate level.

title: RE: Speakeasy C2D outputs

I could never just buy one sight unseen or unheard.I am still rather intrigued by the Speakeasy Modeling Amp though, as it purports to address a very real need in the market. I just wish the company inspired any confidence at all.

title: C1 and a 715
post_content: I have had a C1 now for some time and really enjoy it. The action the effects are all first rate. The leslie sim is very usable for most gigs. In my home studio I have been using studio monitors which have been fine. At gigs I have used the PA or used powered speakers.. BUT I have always wanted a REAL leslie. Most people say only a 122,147,145 will do but I just didn’t have the money for one in good shape. I read the blogs and it seems that everyone is in the same position so I thought I would report what has just worked for me. I saw on craigslist a Leslie 715 for $300 with a beautiful cabinet. It was 2 hours away but I thought what the heck for $300. I have done some research on the 715 and other sold state leslies for some time but I always discounted them because they weren’t REAL leslies. Well I got to tell you this thing in my home studio is the best sound that I have heard in a long time. It came with an 11 pin cable that plugged right in the C1. All functions worked perfectly leslie control fast/slow/brake all worked just like the sim switching. I wasn’t sure that the effects would come through the 11 pin but reverb, gain, and delay all sounded perfect. This is probably the best $300 that I have spent on a musical instrument in a long time. Anyway the point is if you can’t afford a 122 with the preamp issues or the connecting cable requirements. Pick up one of these sweet little units (44 in tall and 170 lbs.) and have a great time for a little money.Jim

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: Jimmyp wrote:Pick up one of these sweet little units (44 in tall and 170 lbs.)Ha, your definition of 'little' differs from mineGlad to hear the 715 works well for you.Btw. I wouldn't be able to tell the difference between a Hammond and a Hapi...

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: The 715 has an upper driver-rotary horn (with it's own solid-state amp) a 15" woofer, without a rotating baffle, and some 6x9?  It was a two-channel job?It's got the essential upper horn, and the bottom rotor is not as essential, in fact many people disconnect it.(The rotating baffle, not the speaker!)  And the roto-sonic speaker would handle some of that.http://www.seipel.de/pages/archiv/oldie ... 15/715.htm

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: Dear MooserI have come to the conclusion that the bottom rotor is actually the most influential of the two in a leslie and if I am forced to choose then a lower rotor only would me my choice.Reason is that the bulk of the sound goes through the lower rotor.This dawned on med when i added a leslie 110 to my MotionSound pro3x.The Leslie effect addition and the 3d feeling was much bigger adding the 110 than just adding the Motion Sound pro3 and a bass amp.If you have big leslie 122/147/145 etc where it is easy to disconnect the plugs to the motors - dissconnet all but the fast lower. Play with stopped Leslie and 808 000 000 Flip the Leslie switch and hear the room come alive.Now only have the horn connected on fast.Do the same thing. On 808  000 000 sound there is not that much coming out the horn.I got a 130 Lelsie with the hammond BC this unit has a lower drum and a stationary treble driver. It still gives a decent Leslie effect.What you miss on a single rotor system is the lovley sound on registrations with lots of higher drawbars where top comes alice quicker than the lows.If I was forced to choose between lower rotor only and top only rotor I would go for the lower only.

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: "I have come to the conclusion that the bottom rotor is actually the most influential of the two in a leslie and if I am forced to choose then a lower rotor only would me my choice.Reason is that the bulk of the sound goes through the lower rotor."Well, lemme put it this way, flmc: You are probably right, but if I could get hold of a working 715 in good shape for $300, I would jump on it right away, use it and like it.   Even more I'd like it if it had a good case!It all depends on what you might want out of the organ/Leslie. Try 800008888/fast/C3 ("squabble" setting)  without a top horn. Also, the rotating baffle and down-firing woofer eats up a lot of bass.  And a 715 has a Rotosonic speaker which can supply some low-end "throb".    If somebody left a 715 in a basket, wrapped in a blanket, squalling outside my front door, I'd give it a home, no questions asked. And if it plugged directly in with an 11pin cord, I'd adopt it, give it my name, and raise it as my own.That leads me to ask:  Where do the bottom-only Leslies cross-over to the stationary tweeter? I would think the x-over point is much higher than the 800hz. of the traditional Leslie. Wouldn't it be more in the area of 2,000hz?

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: I would suspect that it could be even higher for a 130 3500 hz looking at the tweeter in there . A110 or 120/125 has a single guitartype wideband speaker and no tweeter.The other side of the coin is that below leta say 200 - 250 hz there is vert little modulation. Hence the setup if the 715.On my Nord c2 i sometimes have a separate basscombo amp fed via a 125 Hz lowpass active filter. Gives me a really solid low end. And there is no lessening of the Leslie effect.

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: "The other side of the coin is that below leta say 200 - 250 hz there is vert little modulation. Hence the setup if the 715. "Exactly. And I think it's just amazing that the 11pin plug works with no adaptions!  I do gotta wonder,  when the 715 is connected to a single-channel organ does it still run through all the amps in the 715 and drive all the speakers?  And the 715 has some slide controls for balance or something, on the side.No, if I came home late one night and found a 715 in my bed, I wouldn't kick it out.Wow, I just realised! My 130 has an 11pin cord (it's hooked to an L-100, with a "kit")  it should plug into my C2!  Whoopee!  And the formica finish is waterproof, and the orange brown grill cloth hurtles me instantly into another more terrible world, called the 70's.BTW, flmc, have you tried "unspun" reverb yet?   I would like to hear your thoughts on that.

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: I have made a few tries but i need to hone it a bit. The quality of the reverb has not been good enough yet.I'll be back with more tests

title: RE: C1 and a 715
post_content: "The quality of the reverb has not been good enough yet."My biggest problem has been too much top end on the reverb, which exaggerates key click and percussion. The original spring-reverb was very much a midrange thing, but of course the frequency curve could easily be tailored in the reverb-amp and speaker, to the most complimentary range for the organ. Without that it might require some equalisation or a filter.

title: RE: Affordable Accessories
post_content: One option for a music stand is : if you use either of the ONSTAGE stands: Platform or Z-shaped, you can get the 2nd tier  ( make sure you get the right 2nd tier for the right stand).  I did that, plus i purchased online a 1/4" sheet of plexi-glass, ( actually 2, one 20" wide & one 36" wide) to cross the open gap of the 2nd tier. That works great : if anything too great.  I wound up adding a KORG MICROSTATION & A BOSS 660 DRUM MACHINE. THE 36" wide plexiglass easily holds both units. NOw, when i gig solo, my setup, plus the bass pedals sounds like a whole band   ( NOT the 'one-man-band' syndrome !) If you practise a lot with punching the crash cymbal & the bass-drum in time with your right hand & foot on the bass pedal : WHOO ! You REALLY sound like BAND . I've made 5 CD's with that set up , on a $700 ROLAND CD-2E RECORDER & A MACKIE 802-VLZ .  Everybody tells me that it sounds ultra-professional & Studio Quality   ( at least the AUDIO SOUND !)Unfortunally, I stopp using it for a music stand : NO ROOM.   Robert Nuckels

title: RE: connecting C1 to a Leslie
post_content: Andy you must be from the Seattle area. I have been looking at this ad for a while. I have talked to him and the only leslie he has that I was interested I was the 910 with a preamp but it was way to big for me. title: RE: connecting C1 to a Leslie
post_content: "Yes, Jimmyp, I am in Tacoma! Thanks for the info."I'm up here in Kidnap County. You know, Bummertown?  It's right near Poor Tortured.Yup, you're dealing with the remains of Puget Sound Organ Service, in Tacoma. The owner passed away, and over half a century's accumulation of organs, speakers and organ parts (NOS and take-out) for every brand of electronic organ is being very carelessly disposed of.  I bought a new style "Leslie Control Center" switch (avoid that one!) and Roger's (the tech) Trplett 650 vacuum-tube VOM ($ 5)I gotta wonder, was any electronic consumer product as overpriced as electronic organs (Except for the Hammond, a good product at a good price)?  And did anything else lose it's value quite so fast?  In 2003 you buy a Lowery at Prosser's for $30,000 and ten years later, it's gonna end up at the dump, you can't get anything for it on Craigslist.  Ah, the organ salesman must have been a rare breed!!  Able to sense dementia in suburban males years before a doctor can, and even better at scenting excesspelf!  What an ignominious fall, from $30,000 three-manual Lowery's, to slinging to hot tubs!"But you don't have to know how to play! It plays itself! Just sign here."You know, a person could put together a very good exhibit showing every phase of electronic manufacturing progress from hand-soldered, point-to-point wired, glass envelope tubes and  punched-steel chassis to micro-processors, digital circuits and modularised components using free home organs from Craigslist.  Of course, a person could do a lot of other stuff, too. I guess it's up to you.

title: Midi out on C2  Bass pedals

I went through the manual and could not find any reference to this scenario. The pedal in use are Crumar Mojo pedals, which can be touch sensitive.  Connecting the pedals directly to the module  give lots of volume, as does using the lower manual from the C2 on channel 3. My option at this point seems to be a midi-solutions through box. title: RE: Midi out on C2  Bass pedals
post_content: The issue is that the volume parameter is set to 1. I checked with midiox.My board sends 64. The worksround solution is to turn off the velocity on the receiving unit if possible.

title: RE: How an early Hammond sounds

When a Pastor bought i by chance. He had it until I bought it two weeks ago.The organ has dual Tonegenerators. The second one is the chorus generator that acts a the extra strings on a tvelve string guitar.The organ still has the early crome ratchet drawbars and I intend to keep it this way.The keys are tte early "sharp edge" ones but it is not as bad as everyone said. You do palm smears or the nails.The action is gorgous. Very little sideways play. It clicks just as it should and no settings to worry about. It is a take it or leave it organ.The top end is edgier on the esrly organs since they did not have the tapering that compensates for the topend folback.Next steps is fixing the missing tones and reinstall the tube amp.I also have a M100 TG with the scanner and delay line intactSo I plan to use it sitting beside the organ to give me a scanner vibrato.In my workshop I have the chassis from an L100 so with that i should be able to design at percussion circuit and a vibrato non vibrato pre amp. Also use the poweramp to give me nice distorsion.This unit will also sit on the outside since all mods have to be nonintrusive in order to keep her original.Hope all is well with you.

title: Bass pedals - Roland PK-25 vs PK-7
post_content: HiI am thinking of adding bass footpedals to my Nord Stage 2 to get an introduction into organ playing. (Of course, I will only be able to play with one keyboard manual since the MIDI jack will be taken up by the foot pedals.)I thought I would ask the organists in the forum what the difference between pedals like the Roland PK-25 and the Roland PK-9 and PK-7a would be, and whether there is an advantage of one over the other. The Roland Pk-25 has more keys, of course, and is closer to the Nord Pedal Keys in terms of design.  The Roland PK-9 and 7a have fewer keys.  Is there any significant difference in terms of playability and technique?Finally, do you know whethere these bass pedalboards work seamlessly with the Nord Stage via a MIDI cable? I presume they would need their own external power.  Great if anyone should share experience using these pedals with Nord.Pedals are listed here on the Roland website:www.rolandus.com/products/category/468Thanks!

title: RE: Bass pedals - Roland PK-25 vs PK-7
post_content: I use the PK7a with both the C1 and C2d and it works seamlessly with both.  Prior to that I used a PK5 but found that (13 pedals) too limiting.  Prior to that, the full pedalboard of my old B3 and C3 and CV.  If I like and keep the the KeyB Duo Mk111 I hope to be getting in the next week or so, I will likely get the KeyB 25 pedal pedalboard.If you are a trained organist and use proper heel/toe technique, you will likely want a 25 pedal pedalboard, although several good organist (Alan McPike comes to mind)  do very well with smaller boards.  I play in the traditional Jimmy Smith/Joey D/Tony Monaco style and therefore play a lot of left hand bass but I have a long-standing habit of duplicating my hand bass with the pedals so that i can operate the drawbars and/or other controls without losing the bass line.  It soon becomes second nature, especially if you started that way.  A lot of jazz players just tap the pedal (usually the 'A' pedal) to put an attact on the (hand-played) bass note.  That, plus proper use of the expression pedal and a 'stacatto' way of playing the left-hand bass line, works pretty well.  Like everything else, practice makes perfect.  BTW, I play pedals-only on slow tunes.  Again, your needs will depend on the type/style of organ (music) you play.chas

title: RE: Bass pedals - Roland PK-25 vs PK-7
post_content: The PK_7 is excellent !  They are my 3rd set of pedals. I had a 1 octave & 2-octave . the long pedals of the pk 25 are great, but very awkward to transport, because in addition to the pedals themselves, you have to also transport a large enough bench to scan the the 40 to 42 inch width of the pedals. The PK7 has more than just the puny 1 octave set, but are short enough to use a much smaller bench . the pk7 looks great with the Nord, & is much more impressive looking than a 1 octave pedalboard .  I had a road case built that can easily accomodate the 35" width of the PK7a. This pedalboard is built like a tank . as long as you routinely dust them, the contacts will stay clean. They weigh 34 lb.s, & have excellent electronics.

title: RE: Bass pedals - Roland PK-25 vs PK-7
post_content: By all means, get a pedalbord. Like cgiles said above, having those pedals is the anchor to organ continuity : changing programs, pulling drawbars (or draw buttons ) & if have a drum machine for solo gigs , you can also punch in breaks with crash cymbal,bass drum with 2 fingers of your left hand, && punching the bass note on the pedalboard.  It takes lots of practise, but boy,,,,,,,is it EVER worth it .  I've made 5 cd's with that kind of set-up, along with a small Korg micro station on an upper tier. I mount the drum machine & extra keyboard over a custom-made, 5/8" sheet of plexiglass.  With a wide enough onstage z=stand, you've got the WHOLE BAND for a solo or duo gig .One thing to keep in mind, though, if you are going to add a pedalboard : the notes have to be precise & LONG enough to support what goes on upstairs. If the bass line ( especially  when doing the whole bass on pedals ) is lacking, even the most virtuosic thing upstairs will be meaningless. THE BASS LINE IS THE FOUNDATION FOR SELF-CONTAINED organ playing : especially when playing Jazz,funk, Brazilian, etc.

title: C2D with extra voices! Future??
post_content: I think the C2D and the SK2 are hopefully the start of a trend in light weight dual manual keyboards.I'm hoping both Hammond and Nord will continue to innovate in this area.If Hammond can create a dual manual organ with extra voices, Nord can definitely do this.Hopefully Nord are finding a demand for a fully functioning portable B3 and will continue to develop it with even more usability.I really hope Nord can integrate the SK2 idea with extra voices on the C2D.With Nord's superior EP, Clav and Piano sounds, if they brought out their version of the SK2 it would be much more effective than the current SK2.It seems it would be such a waste to not integrate the Electros functionality into the C2d.The C2d idea would then become useful for many other players who would love 2 manuals and the ability to access great Organ, EP and Piano sounds across these manuals.I guess Nord has already started with the Electro 4D .Now just make it 2 manuals and add some extra sets of drawbars!!!

title: RE: C2D with extra voices! Future??
post_content: We'll see!

title: RE: C2D with extra voices! Future??
post_content: Nope, nada, negatory. The C2 and  C2D are ORGANS. Every bit of microprocessor in them is devoted to running the organ engines.  And with the C2D, I'm pretty sure (and honestly, how often am I wrong?)  I think Nord has made the new B-3. The new standard organ. Right size, right features, right price, right weight.   The C2D is the B3 of the 21st-and-a-half Century.Of course, it does occur to me that the "pipe organ" is sample-based, not engine-based.  Sure does seem like piano or string samples could be substituted for, or added to, the pipe organ samples. That does occur to me.  I guess I was disappointed when I found out it couldn't be done from the Nord Sample Library or something.There's a gazillion multi-purpose keyboards, but there's only one C2D (or C1 or C2) It's an organ. An SK2 is an SK1 with an extra keyboard,  the C2D is a two manual organ.No, as the young man wailed about Brittany Spears:  'Leave the C2D  aloooooone!'(Disclaimer:  This is my tentative and timidly offered opinion, which I am prepared to change instantly if anybody even looks sideways at me.)

title: RE: C2D with extra voices! Future??
post_content: Let the c2d just be an organ!!!If you want extra voices go for ns, ne or sk1/2.

title: RE: C2D with extra voices! Future??
post_content: I dont know any working keyboardist besides a full time hammondplayer (let's be real here) who wouldnt enjoy the flexibility of pullingup an ep/ clav or piano on a gig.Yes, the C2d is a fully featured hammond.We're living in 2013.The C2d could remain as it is with the additionof extra voices and the integrity of its organ personawould go unchanged.I think Hammond have tapped into this idea, but theextra voices lack class and there is only one set of drawbars.I will be purchasing the C2d soon but it will be used asa pure hammond 50% of the time at best.The other 50% of the time will be spent triggering pianos, clavs and epsfrom a motif rack.I would happily pay upto another $1000 to have those extrasounds in one board.For me, it's about technology making MORE thingspossible.The technology that has brought us a very portable hammondis fantastic!!

title: RE: C2D with extra voices! Future??
post_content: No matter how many voices a C2D (or other hammond clone) has, it only has 61 note manuals.  Will that be enough for piano-based playing?Although, I gotta admit, I would not have been disappointed if some of the "pipe-organ" sample based programs could be switched out for other voices? I mean, if they're just samples, why not others? (This is something Pablo might know) Maybe an orchestral stop in which each LED (or physical) drawbar controls the volume of certain instruments?And I know that every body assumes (I guess from all the lights and buttons) it makes all the sounds.  They don't quite know what to make of the organ-only aspect of it, like you say, this is 2013.Doesn't Roland make a two-manual (an Atelier Combo?) with a 76 note bottom, weighted, and an upper, with drawbars, Leslie sim?  It is quite a bit bigger, and maybe in the 5-7K$ range?

title: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: Hi All,Newbie C2D owner - newbie clonewheel of any kind owner, actually.Just curious to know what adjustments anyone has made to make the C2D rotary sound more realistic.  I'd rather not resort to a Ventilator right now.To my unsophisticated ears, the fast speed sounds a little too fast, and it ramps up a little to quickly.  What other adjustments would you make?I've read all previous posts but just wondering what others have come up with more recently.  Please comment.Thanks in advance.BC

title: RE: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: To adjust the Leslie sim go into the "Sound" menu, where you will find adjustments for top and bottom speeds, ramps, and volume ratio.Check your manual for the specific directions for the C2D.Are you playing into a board, or playing through amps?  I do believe the "sim" effect will sound better in stereo, with two discrete amp-speakers.I have not had much luck with Leslie sim through one keyboard amp.Hope that helps.   But why not get a real Leslie for your C2D?

title: RE: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: I agree with Mooser. Sims are ok but a real leslie is a revelation.

title: RE: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: flmc59 wrote:I agree with Mooser. Sims are ok but a real leslie is a revelation.

title: RE: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: The real leslie is a revelation' but the internal sim is excellent when recording direct onto an sd card for transfer to a marketable cd. I've done it 4 times, & i know that I liked it ! Also, the internal sim sounds good when running thru a PA.

title: RE: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: I might mention (try and stop me)  that I read that Jim Alfredson (ofhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vn0lxsa0ATkOrganissimo) uses his Leslie switch to operatebothhis "sim" and his real Leslie. The real Leslie is for the stage, and the "sim" goes to the PA.And I could timidly suggest (shoulda stopped me the first time!) that if I am not mistaken, a new "Vent" will run you, in the US, about what you could buy a vintage Leslie for, more or less.  I mean, just saying.And as far as "keyboard amps" go, I'd just get a good pair of powered speakers.  Everything else you need (volume, equaliser, effects) is right there on your C2D.At present, I am working on a "turbo" or "supercharged" Leslie.   The rotating assemblies (horn on top, rotor on bottom) are coupled with  a fan, which pumps air through the cabinet and out the vents, which are specially finished to create vortexes as the air flows through, with the sound.Don't tell anybody, it's a secret.

title: RE: C2D Rotary Sim Settings
post_content: I have a relay box with three relays trigger from one switch.So i have run two leslies and the internal sim at the same time.And I always send the sim outs to the house PA rather than taking the chance on someone doing a bad mike job.

title: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw
post_content: I stand by my earlier post on impressions of the C2 versus the C2D, with one major exception, which I am now discovering.When you pull up a preset on the C2D, you cannot tweak that preset using the drawbars unless you hold down the selected Preset key in the panel to the left of the manual.  To do so, you have to take both hands off the keyboard - using one to hold the Preset key down and then adjusting a drawbar with the other - which makes the drawbars completely useless in changing the sound live in real time.  But that is really the major reason to buy a C2D versus the C2!It is technically true that there is no connection between the presets and the drawbars in a real Hammond made 50+ years ago, which I have to believe was the "logic" behind this programming decision.  But it is also true that no one I know has ever used the preset keys on a real Hammond.  When playing the Beast, you learn to use the drawbars alone.The C2 and the C1 work exactly as I would expect in today's age - the preset calls up a registration and you can then quickly tweak any drawbar to your heart's content in real time by using the up and down buttons below the drawbar, using the other hand to play (often holding notes to focus attention on the changing sound).  So you get the benefit of a quick preset and also the benefit of real time adjustment to the sound.  Perfect.  That is not the case on the C2D!The bottom line is that the presets on the C2D are just as useless as they are on a real Hammond, which totally defeats the benefits of the drawbars when using any of the presets.  The drawbars are only live when you select the A or B drawbar buttons, or if you hold the preset key down before you adjust them.I'm still stunned.  So I now have to assess whether this is a problem that Nord will fix quickly with an OS update, or whether I should just return the C2D and keep my C2.

title: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw

title: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw
post_content: Å

title: RE: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw
post_content: Personally, I much prefer the way the C1 and C2 are set up.  The preset calls up a registration and its appropriate effects.  The physical position of the drawbars is not connected to the preset registration (the lights on the C1/C2 make that possible but the physical drawbars on the C2D make it impossible, which is fine).But I would like any drawbar that is moved to adjust the preset accordingly, jumping to whatever position the drawbar is in.  That lets me change the sound on the fly, regardless of whether I start with the drawbar panels active, or a preset active.  You can make a change to the preset registration in the C2D if you hold down the preset button, but that forces me to take me hands off the keyboard, which I don't want to do in a live situation.Example:  I pull up a preset and begin to play in a live situation.  Assume that it has no 1' drawbar in the preset.  As I get to the chorus of the song, I want to add a bit of 1' drawbar to that preset to give the sound a little more top end.  I then want to remove that 1' sound as I get back into a verse.  Since I need all the hands I can use (and then some) to play and adjust the drawbar, I want to be able to do that without having to hold the Preset key down.  I don't want to save the preset, so I'm fine having the sound revert back to the original preset when I change to another.  I just want to be able to change the sound on the fly in a live situation, even if I start from a preset.Does that make sense?  I definitely don't think I would be alone in that preference, but if others want to weigh in, that would be great.

title: RE: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw
post_content: The other big improvement on the C2D for me would be for it to behave like the Stage 2 in revealing the underlying programming.  On the Stage 2, if you hold the Shift key and then move any of the physical controls that are not already displayed with the lights, it shows the program position for that control in the display.  Terrific benefit for those of us who want to know how a factory preset is programmed.On the C2D, it would be terrific if that same kind of feature worked to reveal the underlying registrations for each preset (as well as the programmed settings for overdrive, etc.).  Hold the shift key down and move any drawbar that has the LED lit above it (indicating that it is active), and the programmed position of that drawbar in the preset is displayed.Alternatively, Nord could just publish a spreadsheet of some kind that has the registrations and effects settings for the factory presets.  Users who just pick a preset and play won't care, but the C2D is targeted to people like me who really do care about registrations.  I want to know what the presets are programmed to.  Easily visible on the C1 and C2, and any other organ that has a display.  But hidden on the new C2D.

title: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw
post_content: I agree with you on preset issueEvery time you hit preset it preloads with the saved setting but the drawbars are still active. Question is if it should be the a or b set pr both.If you want to revert you just hit the preset again

title: RE: Updated impression of C2D - a near-fatal flaw
post_content: Good question on the active drawbar set.  Seems to me that the active drawbars should be the set that is active in the preset (denoted by the single LED above each active drawbar).  I think that is A in all or almost all of the presets, but I don't have enough experience so far to know for sure.Agree with you on the revert issue.  If you want to cancel any changes you make to any drawbar settings, just hit the preset again and it reloads the saved settings.  Physical drawbars are out of the picture until one or more is moved, in which case the new physical position, for those drawbars only, overrides the preset.  The saved setting are still valid for drawbars that have not been touched.  That's the way almost every clone I know works these days, including all the Nord products that have the lit drawbars.  Why it is different on the C2D is the mystery, at least to me.

Can't help thinking of a way to combine the advantages of both.But apart from that detail, putting the full 4-sets plus pedal of real drawbars on the C2D was the best thing anybody's done for the clonewheel organ in a long time. Before the C2D the only other organ to offer the full set of physical drawbars are the expensive and heavy B3MkII  models from Hammond.

title: Using the drawbars as midi controllers
post_content: Today I manage to "Marry" my C2d and my Yamaha motif es rack.I use the B set drawbars on the lower as  volume control = drawbar functionI have set up a multi on the Motif as followsDrawbar 1 = Double bass for lower manual splitted (in motif)Drawbar 2 = Rhodes (same octave as 888 000 000) split in motif (for use with db1)Drawbar 3 = empty nowDrawbar 4 = Rhodes (same octave as 008 800 000) no splitDrawbar 5 = Rhodes (same octave as 888 000 000) no splitBass 8' drawbar - double bass sound on channel 3. This sound is set at high volume so I only have to pull it to 3.I will have to rely on db set A for the  organsounds since the B set is now used for controlling the extra sounds.Rhodes sounds blends well with the organ sounds.The trick is to let the organ dominate the sound

title: RE: Something loose is rolling around inside my C2
post_content: Dennis wrote:I hope this is the proper forum for my question.It isDennis wrote:Is this a common problem?It's not a common problem, but it just so happens someone with a Nord Electro had a similar issue very recently. Have a look at this thread:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-elect ... t4201.htmlDennis wrote:What is the best way to open the case to inspect?It is of course better not to do it yourself, but sometimes you might need to do so anyway. If you can use a screwdriver and can carefully/patiently open your Nord you should be able to do it though. This is however completely at your own risk and you can certainly do damage to your instrument (the flat cables between the top panel and the keybeds are the most easily damaged parts when doing this).I've never had a C2 open myself so can't speak from experience, but I expect it to require a procedure similar to what you'd have on an Electro, Stage, Lead, etc. It is much higher though and has two manuals, so there might be more than 1-2 screws on the bottom you need to remove.In the post with the picture of the electro (see the thread I linked earlier), I give a short procedure. I think you need to remove the side panels, the row of screws on the back (the big ones) and the 'odd ones out' on the bottom (probably roughly in the middle, left-right). Don't remove any of the screws used for mounting the keybed(s) to the bottom (their mounted in rows of multiple screws). Once you've removed the right screws, the top panel should lift right off. I think all the screws you need to remove will have a fine thread on them (they screw into metal). If you remove screws with a very coarse thread (self-tappers), you probably removed some screw that's part of the keybed - screw it back, but make sure you don't overtighten it (that might crack the plastic frame of the keybed).It would be helpful for me if you could make (and post) a picture of the bottom of your C2 (ideally showing which screws you had to remove), a picture of the inside (close-up of the main circuit board, I'm curious as to what's in that particular Nord), a picture showing the two manuals and how they are fixed to the instrument. If there are less than four flat cables going from the keybeds to the main circuit board, I'd also be interested in a shot of both ends of any cables that do connect the keybeds to the main circuit board. A shot of the bottom of the top panel showing the standoff(s) that rest on the bottom of the C2 would be interesting too.Since you seem to be living in the US, you could contact Nord Tech Support USA (http://www.proaudioe.com/pages/nord-tec ... rt-usa.php) about this. Pablo might have some ideas and more information.

title: RE: Pipe organ upper manual can barely be hard over lower manual
post_content: The problem is the volume of the pipes in the swell ranks.This is normal organ behaviour.First of all have the swell pedal on max.The swell pedal only affects the swell manual.When the pedal is on max you still have to go easy on the number of stops used on the great manual.Using the reed stops helps to bring out the great manual.

title: RE: Pipe organ upper manual can barely be hard over lower manual
post_content: "But I purchased the Nord for the brilliant B3 tone"I think Nord agrees, and the decision to use the five physical drawbar sets announces the supremacy of the B3 model in the C2D organ hierarchy.  And everybody seems to agree it was a brilliant decision, and whatever convenience is lost on the pipe, VX and Farf settings (from the LED-drawbutton models) is more than compensated for by the improvement in B-3 emulation, the physical drawbars. And whoever doesn't agree probably has some weird fear about being injured by drawbars, which are nearly harmless. I've even learned not to get my fingers caught in them.BTW, the B-3, Vx, and Farf organs are driven by "digital organ engines" but the pipe organ is sample-based.

title: RE: Pipe organ upper manual can barely be hard over lower manual
post_content: The advantage of the dual drawbarsets extends to the pipeorgan as well. You can preset the sound and then switch to the new set of stops.Btw I had missed the swell level adjustment. I primarily use the B3 sound.

title: RE: Pipe organ upper manual can barely be hard over lower manual
post_content: "Btw I had missed the swell level adjustment."Ah-ha!, whern I took the plate of food off the right side of my C2 (Try that with your C2D!)  I discovered No.13 on the "Sound" menu is "Pipe pedal level"  and No. 14  "Pipe swell level"   Of course, with all those drawbars festooning the top of your C2D, there's no place to print the menus.Gosh, all that convenience, gone, just to get a couple more sets drawbars!What were they thinking?"You can preset the sound and then switch to the new set of stops."If I am not mistaken (always a real good possibility) the "preview" button on a C2  does that, too.Not, of course, like I'm saying if Fed-Ex dropped off a C2D at my house I would turn it down, or anything.  But us C2 owners (and I bought mine just a few months before the C2D was released!)  have to try and save face, somehow.And may the C2D  obtain the ubiquity it truly deserves!

title: RE: Pipe organ upper manual can barely be hard over lower manual
post_content: "I still have my c1 and c2 and love them both"In that case, maybe I can do you a favor. Believe me, I know what it is to have too many organs around the house! title: Nord C2 32 note pedalboard w toe studs
post_content: Hello all,I'm planning on making a set of midified pedals for my nord C2 this Christmas break. I was messing around with the MIDI cc settings and found that I can scroll through the presets (the 1,2,3 buttons above the drawbutton leds) on MIDI controller cc #3 but it is on a continuous scale (via the extern pot on my stage ex). I'm curious how I could set up a seperate toe piston device to select the presets while in Pipe Organ mode (B3 i don't have to worry since I usually have a free hand). It wouldn't have to be 6 different pistons, I would be happy if I could just kick a single piston to move through the presets 1 to (6), one by one. Being new to designing any kind of midi device I was wondering if anyone have any ideas? Also any good suggestions for a midi interface/adapter for a 32 note organ pedal board?ThanksMicah

title: RE: Nord C2 32 note pedalboard w toe studs
post_content: On my pedalboard only the highest note (G) will not trigger in pipe organ mode. Not a big deal since it's not typically used. I can couple both the great and the swell stops (only one at a time) which sound on all ~31 notes. -side note, the MIDI cpu that I used can be programmed to sound at any octave so for a while I had 32' stops. I might look into an octave shift function sometime in the future since this could really open up the registration possibilities for the Nord.The AGO 32 note pedalboard is concave and radiating so it makes it more anatomically nice to play. I'm not sure why the length of the notes is so much longer mine pivot on the back under the bench but the narrowing due to the radiation lets me put the bench under no problem. I built the pedals and studs mainly for the pipe organ samples anyways.

title: Lower manual problem
post_content: I just got delivery of a new Nord C2D and have the following problem:The tones of the lower manual are completely mixed up. The manual is starting with the higher half of the tones, a "C" actually sounding like an Minor A. About half way up, a few heys are silent and then it restarts with the low tones (a C souding like an E), those you would have expected in the low half of the manual. For th rest, the organ is behaving as it should.Is there any settings that can cause this and that I ca change or has Nord mixed up a couple of cables in the instrument in th production? In that case, They can never have botherd to test it before shipping. A clue anyone?

title: RE: Lower manual problem
post_content: Do you play "pedal to Great" lh bass?Try press that Button off and play and listen. Maybe you play with headphones and that will cut the lower freq of the tones.

title: RE: Lower manual problem
post_content: Thank you for your suggestion! I tried that but unfortunately it did not make any difference. However, it gave me a clearer picture of the problem. The manual works equally "well" with both settings that you mention. The problem, however, is that the tone that should be the lowest C is connected to the third A from the left, the third B (H in out Swedish terms) gives me the tone of the lowest D etcetera. The lowest key deliver a rather high A minor which whould have been connected to a A minor somewhere in the middle of the keyboard. I get a stronger and stronger feeling that there are some cables inside which have been mixed up but any other suggestion will be gratefully considered.

title: RE: Lower manual problem
post_content: Är du svensk? Are you from Sweden( cant see your nationality on my iphone) the term H is/was most common in Germany/Sweden years ago. Today we say B and Bb. Some people said B for Bb at the H era.Are you familiar with the drawbars. It sounds like a "fraction" drawbar is colouring the tone of c. It adds other intervalls than octaves.

title: RE: Lower manual problem
post_content: 5 1/3 add à G and 1 3/5 add à E (5 in a minor).If your speaker cut the low c and you just hear the adding intervalls of am7 ?

title: RE: Lower manual problem

Have been a Hammond owner from approx 1970 - 2003 (P100, T122 and B3), a long time long time ago (hence my use of "H" instead of "B"). The drawbars on my new Nord C2D works perfect. The problem is just that each tone is related to the wrong key. Apart from that, all the drawbars and the rest as well works perfectly normal. Thank you for your input anyway.

title: Nord Pedal Keys 27 settings?
post_content: Hi. I just bought the nord pedal keys 27. There is no choose for this in the swell pedal settings in nord c2d. Is the default settings (Roland ev5) the best for the exp pedal at the nord pedal keys 27? Or is another setting better?

title: RE: Nord Pedal Keys 27 settings?
post_content: Try them.  See which curve gives you a pleasing swell pedal action, and volume-tone curve (both, I believe, change throughout the swell pedal throw, as it is modeled on the old Hammond variable-capacitor volume pedal, the best one ever made for an organ.)  If the pedal-keys sends volume change messages through the MIDI plug, and doesn't have it's own TRS plug, it may not go through those settings, and is probably set to emulate a Hammond swell pedal in the B3 mode, I would think.

title: RE: Nord Pedal Keys 27 settings?
post_content: The default is NOT the best with pedal keys and leslie 3300.  I have tried them all and my favorite is the second Roland type (7). Softer and more linear and the drive comes in at the last 20-10%.

title: RE: Nord Pedal Keys 27 settings?
post_content: Hammonds are usually very sensitive in the first part of the travel of the volume pedal.

title: RE: Nord Pedal Keys 27 settings?
post_content: "Hammonds are usually very sensitive in the first part of the travel of the volume pedal."As I understand it, since a variable capacitor is used instead of a pot. both the volume and tone balance change throughout the range.  And the volume "pop" of a Hammond pedal is like nothing else I've ever found.  Ever try the rolling-contact-on-carbon-plate type volume pedal that was in Baldwin organs?   Terrible, and got worse as the carbon wore away.Much releived to find out I'm not the only one using the 'wrong' setting for my pedal. I use the 'Ro' setting, too.

title: RE: Nord Pedal Keys 27 settings?
post_content: I just switched from the Yamaha to the Roland setting and like it better.  It seems I'm now able get more distortion out of my 3300 w/out putting the pedal all the way down.

title: RE: Half Moon Switch too expensive, selfmade?
post_content: I was sifting through the last remaining stocks of left-over (most everything else has been sold) parts from the now, sadly, defunct Puget Sound Organ Service company, and of course, not a half-moon switch remained. Except one entirely home-made copy of a half-moon, made out of wood, with a toggle switch.But there were quite a few of the newer "Leslie Control Center" switch clusters available, cheap ($10.00).  I'm going to try one on my Nord C-2, as it should mount to the holes provided.  They are not as good as half-moon style switches, but they are better than a foot-switch, for me. Working on that right now.The slickest Leslie switch I've seen is a gadget which mounts in the traditional position, and uses either (I'm not sure which) a photo-device or body-capacitance to switch Leslie speeds when you pass your finger across its surface, a smooth wooden strip.

title: RE: Half Moon Switch too expensive, selfmade?
post_content: Ho-Kay! The Leslie control center is done. with tri-color LED speed indicator, and velcro mount to the organ. Friend Barry put it together in between keeping public TV on the air.  I'll attempt to take a couple of pictures and load them in.  It's not the best in the world, but it's a big improvement on a footswitch.  It's in the right place (lower left hand side) and the switch flicks easily.By the way, you wanna see a guy who can flip the hell out of a Leslie switch, but tenderly, even on an alternate take?

title: RE: Half Moon Switch too expensive, selfmade?

title: RE: Nord c2d + 3300 vs new B3 + 122xb
post_content: Do you plan to take it out, or will it sit in your home?  If you play out, I can't think of a better alternative than the C2D+3300.   You got one heavy-ish piece, but it's already got wheels and handles, and the C2D is an easy lift. One cord, and you're done. If I am not mistaken (and it's easier to type that then look it up) the "new B-3" models from Hammond Suzuki weigh about the same as a vintage B-3. Do they weight them?  And wood-finish Leslies get so beaten-up when they're trundled around.  Does a 122xb even have a "line out" for  PA reinforcement?  One thing the Hammond has is the nine-contact keys-switches, if that makes a significant difference to you.You can't go wrong with a C2D. Wait a minute, I just noticed the flag. title: RE: pa speaker or keyboard amp for c1, any recommendation?
post_content: The advantages to using a powered PA speaker with a Pro3x or Vent+Nord instead of a keyboard amp are, first, you don't need the pre-amp and eq, all that is on your organ, 3X and controls on the Vent.  In fact, I have always plugged the output from the 3X into the "main amp in" jack on the peavey and skipped the awful-sounding pre-amp, useless eq and compression.  Both the Nord and the 3X have an output which is hot enough to drive any main amp, and needs no further pre-amp.Also, powered speakers tend to have very powerful Class D amps, and be much lighter then keyboard amps (unless you must have a Baltic birch-ply cabinet and 2- 15"s, those get heavy!)  Make sure the inputs are combo-plugs or 1/4' unbalanced inputs are available, or you'll need adapters.  And the powered speaker can be used as a "bottom" for a Pro3X, which is 800hz and down (it'll x-over about 2k, and probably be bi-amped) and then it's full range can be used for piano, synth.BTW, the Peavey powered speaker I tried (115D) had the same coarse sound as the KBA-100.  To me, it doesn't seem to work well for the organ, and it doesn't do good things for the Leslie sim. I would look for something smoother-sounding

title: RE: pa speaker or keyboard amp for c1, any recommendation?

Besides being a useful source of info, wow, if you've been around these things most of your life, the memories they dredge up.  Why did I ever let my Vox Jaguar go?  Oh, for the days of orange day-glo Kustom amps! Where have they gone?http://www.combo-organ.com/BTW, there's a gazillion powered speakers out there, under various brands, many put together from contract components or stock parts.  Quality, and sound can differ a lot, even to different units of the same model. Try to hear them before you accept them, or make sure you can bring it back and exchange it.  And in my opinion, those "800 watt, class D" amplifiers will quickly overpower the cabinet in many cases, if they're used on the floor.  And it's not unknown to blow speakers, or get non-working units (I got 2!)  The high-quality brands are correspondingly more expensive, of course.

title: RE: pa speaker or keyboard amp for c1, any recommendation?
post_content: You need something with spinning reflectors.either a 9 pin transistor leslie, a solton cabinet, or a big sharma cabinet.The Nord organ makes a good "145" cabinet with the leslie stopped, you put the stopped signal through a transistor cabinet (make sure the horn and rotor are counter rotating - some are not) and it will blow you away.I am convinced (having owned a C3 and 147) that a Nord through a Sharma would be virtually the same thing to most ears.Never ever ever use a straight cabinet, or a ventilator.You can get a big sharmaleslie for about £100 and they rule. Sure they don't rule when you put a C3 through them, but the preamp out sound of a tonewheel organ is like your Nord with the leslie off, through headphones.....it sounds horrible and synthetic.

title: Using a C1 with Modules and a Sequencer
post_content: Hi there, I can't believe I've never seen this forum before! Its good to be here...I've had a Nord C1 for several years. I also have a C2 that I keep at my rehearsal space, but I use the C1 every day to practice and write.Anyways, I use my C1 to control a Roland JV880 and an Alesis Nanobass. In order to utilize velocity sensitivity, I have the MIDI channels set to E1, E2, and E3 for the upper manual, lower manual, and bass section respectively. This works great controlling my modules.It's gets tricky, however, when I use a sequencer to help with writing. I have it set up like thisC1 > MPC1000 > Nanobass > JV880 > C1So the MPC recognizes incoming signals and will play them back. HOWEVER, the C1 will NOT play back the incoming MIDI. If I set the MIDI channels to regular 1,2, & 3, only then will it play back the incoming signal. The tradeoff is I lose all velocity sensitivity on my modules.So EVERYTIME I recorded on the MPC I would have to set the channels to E1, E2, & E3 and EVERYTIME I play back, I would have to REset the channels to standard 1,2, & 3 which is a massive pain the arse.(I have confirmed that it is definitely not the MPC because I get the same results on a Yamaha QY700 and using a computer with Digital Performer.)So...anyone out there encounter this too? Am I screwing something up here? Is there a workaround?Thanks in advance, and again I'm happy to have joined the forum.

title: RE: Using a C1 with Modules and a Sequencer
post_content: Hello Franz and welcome to the forum.Franz Schiller wrote:So EVERYTIME I recorded on the MPC I would have to set the channels to E1, E2, & E3 and EVERYTIME I play back, I would have to REset the channels to standard 1,2, & 3 which is a massive pain the arse.I don't have a C1 nor do I have any experience with one, but I had a look at the manual and I think you are right. I also don't see a way around this (but hopefully there is a trick or something like that).On page 16, it states that for channels 1-16 MIDI IN is enabled, while for E1-E16 MIDI IN isnotenabled. Channels 1-16 give fixed velocity (which is not what you want, but probably the way a real organ reacts) while channels E1-E16 do send velocity data.I think MIDI IN is deactivated when the Nord is generating noteswithvelocity data because the sound engine of the C1 (which is designed to emulate a real organ) does not understand velocity - a real organ is not velocity sensitive (afaik). So it seems they gave the C1 (which itself is not able to do anything useful with velocity data) a keyboard that can register velocity, but in the normal mode of operation (where MIDI IN is active) it does not send this information (it sends a fixed value) via MIDI.

title: RE: Using a C1 with Modules and a Sequencer
post_content: Thanks!Well, i just wanted to at least confirm that and make sure I wasn't overlooking something.I thought about this, and realized I *may* be able to automate the process of changing from the "External" channels to the regular one; my Behringer BCN44 can supposedly "learn" processes, even sysex ones, so once I get a little time, I'll try figuring out how to automate.That way, I can hit a single button before I record, and then after I record, and that will swap the channels. We'll see if that works.Thanks all!

title: RE: Using a C1 with Modules and a Sequencer
post_content: Since you're using DP, I assume you have a Mac. You could download and use this free utility:MIDI MonitorIf you run it with your C1's MIDI outputs connected via a MIDI interface to your Mac, it'll show you what the C1 is sending. If you change channels and the C1 is actually sending some SysEx data (or MIDI CC numbers) you could use that; you could record that with your Behringer (maybe you can also upload data like that to it).However, I suspect there's no way to change the channels using SysEx messages - for that to work a) Nord needs to have implemented that functionality and b) you need to know what SysEx messages to send. But who knows, maybe it does send SysEx data if you try it. MIDI Monitor is a fairly low-complexity way of spying on MIDI data - it can make troubleshooting MIDI issues quite a bit easier, since you can see what you're dealing with (channels used, etc.).

title: Tu-be, or not Tu-be?
post_content: I run my Nord C2 to a Motion Sound Pro3x, with 2 Peavey KBA100 as the bottom.  I don't use (except under unusual circumstances) the Leslie "sim"  nor do I use (much) the "drive" control.  The Motion Sound Pro3x has Fet adjustable overdrive, which can be pretty much tuned out by adjusting the "gain" control, although it can't be turned off.  Not a cathode, anode, glass envelope or heater in the lot! My question to the over-modulationmayvensat the forum is:Would interposing a tube pre-amp between the organ and amp be a good idea?  What, if any are the benefits?  And if it is a good idea, which tube pre-amp would you recommend?I purchased an inexpensive Studio Art tube pre-amp, returned it for another, and both, as far as I could see, were defective (non-working VU meters/lights, extreme noise, pops and clicks etc.) and both returned. Is there another inexpensive tube pre-amp which does work reliably, or should I not bother unless I can get hold of one of the more expensive units?   Is the gain in sound ("warmth", "real tube overdrive") worth the money and extra complication?  Will it be audible in a live setting, or is it mostly for giving warmth to recording?Any suggestions (except that I should go boil my head and stuff a sock in it) will be appreciated.

title: RE: Tu-be, or not Tu-be?
post_content: The 122 sound probably has two components at least.Overdriving the final tube in the B3. Missmatch in the balanced transmission line of the differential first stage in the 122. Overdriving the output tubes in the 122.Distorsion sets it early and slowly increase over the volume range. Most preamp type distorsions has to much on off.

title: RE: Tu-be, or not Tu-be?
post_content: Hey, Dyna-Chord !I've used the SPEAKEASY CLASSIC which i had made when i was still using my Voce clones, as well as the OB3 squared. this one i sold recently on ebay. I also used a SPEAKEASY SHOT-GLASS clone with barker switch , which is now on the market. This Shotglass tube pre amp is a pared down version of the Classic, with just a GAIN switch on the side of the unit, plus a BARKER SWITCH IN THE BACK TO dramatically increase the gain when competting with loud guitars, drums, etc. both of these were used only with 1/4 ", though you can get ones to with leslie pins. The Classic was distinctive for it's ability to remain 'clean' at a louder volume. Bruce Wahler did a review of this clone back in 2002 (?)I've also tried the ART MP STUDIO pre amp which was good.Bear in mind, however, that when i say the ' difference with or without the tube preamp is too subtle for my ears to know the difference' that all of us  tend to hear things different. I make no  claims  to having a highly discerning ear when it comes to hearing certain frequencies, 'latencies, & even certain instances of clipping. I'm partially deaf,s o certain nuances of sound that others with a more practised ear on the technical level . Guys like Mooser, flmc59 probably hear certain things in the signal that i have no clue of .  You may be better off listening to these more informed brothers in rotary. I am one of those people who picked the Nord because i was so GAGA over it's overall sound (especially the DRIVE)  I also had 7 different clones within 1 year, & spent a fortune throwing away money on an endless series of stomp pedals, flangers,effects processers to get that sound, that my signal chains alone were comparable to the CLARK GRISWOLD character's plug-in atrocity in NATIONAL LAMPOON'S CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY. With constant brown-outs, trip failures, getting tangled up in the densely interwoven nightmares of wires & cords, ALL FOR RE-CREATING THE NORD SOUND ; i was so happy to have relative simplicty that I EVEN NEVER BOTHERED TO UPGRADE from vers. 1.32 (?)But you guys on this forum obviously want to get on with the changing world ( and i respect each & ever one of you for doing just that ) so always bear in mind that any post that i posit on ANY of the forums is going to be a by-product of the Modern Pharmiceutical Spectrum of psychological 'chemical refreshment'.   ( manic depression, rapid cycling, cancer,chronic pain, anti-psychotics, & the after effects of Radiation treatment .) if i have offended anyone on this post for posting such weird ramblings, try to understand that the SILENT MAJORITY of Rotary-Club Warriors PROBABLY consists of numerous types in my shoes.  hell, just trying to re-create that glorious sound is enough to drive anyone Area 51.

title: RE: Tu-be, or not Tu-be?
post_content: I used my C1 the other day. With my old homemade drawbar box. "The pidgeons nest"The more i get into to organ playing the more i can get out of the C1.I you mentally assign dual roles to the drawbars you will ger more out of your Nord.Drawbars functions as1. Additative synthesis mixer.2 Graphic EQTake the JS standard sound 888 000 000 C3 percussion third fast soft.You sit in room x and the sound is little boomy. When you solo. Would i then go for the bass in the eq? Nope that would mess up the bass and comp sound in the lower manual.What to do?Pull back the 16' one or two steps. Suddenly the boominess is gone.Same sound 888 000 000 but this time it's hard in the midrange. What to do?Cut back the second (1 octave and a fifth) drawbar a notch.The sound is a little dull?Add a one or two notches of the 8 or 9 drawbar. To att a tiny bit of brilliance.When i hit up a drawbar setting I go for the standard numer first. Then most of the time I will tweak a bit according to my mood/the mood of the song and all else that is going on.If your are in a soft part of the song push the drawbars in a bit.  555 sounds the same as 888 just lower.The life time quest of using the drawbar concept is to learn how each partial influences the mix. McGriff does not sound like JS. I think McGriff often pushed in the 16' a bit in the top manual and used slow deacy or even had the fith drawbar out a bit.Full organ played 888 888 888 can sound horrible.Push in the odds a notch or two and it sounds sweet.So method is when you register is switching between the two modes of regarding the drawbars.1 Start by seeing them as stops.2 Then see them as graphic Eq and tweak the sound so it pleases your ear.It does not matter if you use 888/687/857/ ....... or what ever to get the fundament for a JS sound.  If it sounds good it is good.At the rehearsal I was thinging about getting my C2 instead of using the C1 but I realised that by tweaking the sounds and playing of of the organs capabilitied I got a very good end result.I was using a Motion Sound pro 3x and a cube 60 bass amp.Same thing here. I have adjusted the speeds in unit so they sound good. They are probably not the ideal 0.6 and 6.xx hz.I set them so they  sounded good. And then it works.Also when using the motion sound I will hit c3 when going to tremolo and turn it of when going to chorale.This makes the whole thing sound nicer.

title: RE: How to hook up Hammond XK pedals to C2D
post_content: Oddly enough, I just got hold of a 20 note set of Hammond pedals (XPK-200) to use with my C-2.  The default MIDI channel for organ pedals is 3. The Hammond pedal channels are switched by turning them on (by plugging in the power supply) while holding the highest pedal down, along with a pedal corresponding to the channel you want to select (channel 3 is low D the third pedal) the indicator-pilot light blinks three times, and away you go, by plugging the MIDI cord into the "Pedal" MIDI socket on the Nord.  The pedal drawbars, the "synth bass" or pipe organ pedal stops are now triggered by the pedals, or will play below the split in the lower manual if you desire that too.  The Hammond pedal manual can be accessed on-line.  My only problem has been the lack of a table-style stand, as I had all x-brace, but one is hopefully on the way.Anyway, I'm pretty sure the C2D will work the same.  If you need to you can select otherMIDI channels for the pedals on the Nord, and make sure the pedals and organ are on the same channel.On mine, the expression pedal is held by an adapter and two hand-screws.  By using a piece of sheet metal or velcro, a different pedal, like the FC-7 I use, can be adapted to the pedals, pitting the pedals and swell pedal in standard places.Directions for switching the pedal channel on the Nord using the MIDI Program mode are in the manual.

title: RE: How to hook up Hammond XK pedals to C2D

title: RE: How to hook up Hammond XK pedals to C2D
